urn:contentItem:5RRY-52T1-DYNN-T0CC-00000-00Well beyond interest-free card financing2018-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALWell beyond interest-free card financing

Technological progress and the decline of interest rates are causing deep changes in the Brazilian financial system, a small silent revolution, with dimensions that still go unnoticed. In the last few weeks, the discussion about "interest free" financing via credit card became news, but the measure is only a small sample of what is under discussion. In Brazil, banks are above all pragmatic. They defend their businesses and their gains, but when they realize that the tide is turning they let themselves be carried and embrace the new ideas as if they had been in favor of them since the beginning.

It was like that, for example, with payroll loans, which began at smaller banks, in Minas Gerais, with strong support at the time of the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB). It was also like that with the recent growth of fintech firms. Today, the two largest private-sector banks, Itaú and Bradesco, maintain centers dedicated to startups and innovation companies, Cubo and Habitat. The tide showed banks that these tech companies would bring the new wave of competition in the sector, and not traditional financial institutions. Embracing innovative ideas and supporting smaller companies allowed the Brazilian banks to begin preparing for a much bigger fight on the horizon: the dispute with big tech companies, such as Amazon, Google, Facebook and Apple. Just like media companies, which had to learn to work with these tech firms in a model of competition and partnership at the same time, so do these banks. Last week, for example, Bradesco announced its partnership with Google Pay for account holders who have Visa credit card. The Android app allows paying for purchases without the need of the plastic card or typing PIN. Enough putting the smartphone close to the merchant's point-of-sale terminal - the NFC connectivity allows wireless and secure communication between nearby devices. Apple is expected to launch its Apple Pay soon in Brazil - its website displays the logo of Itaú. The Central Bank is closely monitoring the technological evolution and has been making a series of changes in the rules to allow these advances not to be restricted to the banks' environment, but to reach consumers and companies. The card industry has been receiving special attention. The goal is to have the debit card in fact used as method of payment. To expand its use, it will be necessary to reduce the transaction fee, now a percentage on the value of the transaction that is divided into three components: the card brand's fee, an interchange fee charged by the banks and a cost charged by the merchant acquirer, the company that operates the terminals capturing the transactions. With the arrival of new companies in the acquiring market, such as Eleven and Stone, part of that fee was already reduced. But it is still necessary to discuss the interchange fee charged by banks and that is negotiated between the card brand and the financial institution. In countries such as the US, the fee charged in debit-card transactions is mixed, that is, it includes a fixed amount per transaction and a percentage over the volume of the transaction - $0.20 plus 0.05% of the transaction. The charge is regulated by the government. One expert explains there is room for the Brazilian Central Bank to put pressure on lenders to lower their fees because in a sale with debit card the money is available in the buyer's checking account. There is no credit risk. "It makes no sense having fees for debit and credit so close if the risk of one method and the other is so different." In the case of credit card, there is a lot of controversy about a possible end of the interest-free card financing. The focus of the discussion, however, is of giving transparency to the interest that is included in the transaction - whether it is paid by the consumer to the merchant or to the bank, which would begin to offer a credit facility in the card. Just like the end of hyperinflation led to a cycle of adjustments in banks and retailers, the new phase of lower interest rates is also likely to cause a re-accommodation. Some large retail chains now have an important part of their gains linked to the charge of interest in financed sales, via credit card or not. It is natural, therefore, that big retailers and banks engage in an arms-wrestling to see who will keep that gain. The final design may be that of a purchase having a lower price for upfront payment and two prices for financing via card - one with the interest rate charged by the merchant and another with the rate charged by the bank that extended the credit. Nothing is defined yet. Several designs are being studied and in all the expectation is a reduction in the timeframe for payment to the retailer, now of 30 days. For companies, the government has been working since last year in formatting the electronic trade bill - which now entered the package of measures of President Michel Temer to replace the vacuum left by the pension reform. The trade bill will be linked to the tax databases of state finance secretariats. The goal is to match the physical transaction to the commercial and financial transaction, without the need of validation by notary offices. That lowers the bureaucracy and the cost (with expected reduction in rates charges for advances on receivables) and increases the transparency and the formality. The electronic trade bill will be optional - the traditional one will continue being accepted across the country. After all, as one source following the process says, technology has greatly advanced and continues advancing, but one can't forget that Brazil has large regional differences. It is not possible to compare the technological infrastructure of Faria Lima Avenue, the financial hub in SãoPaulo, with that of a city in the heart of the Amazon. What is possible to say is that in five years the relation of consumers and companies with methods of payment and credit will be totally different from the current one.

urn:contentItem:5S3R-YY41-JCJY-G4SC-00000-00Well, duh - Mark Zuckerberg's trip to DC was classic sci-fi;Snow Crash, techies' favourite novel, shows how they baffle law makers2018-04-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisCOMMENTVersion:1Well, duh - Mark Zuckerberg's trip to DC was classic sci-fiSnow Crash, techies' favourite novel, shows how they baffle law makersNiall Ferguson

I stopped reading science fiction when I turned 17. I thought reading history would give me better insights into the future. The trouble with sci-fi is that it always predicts 10 out of the next three technological innovations. The future is never as weird in reality as it is in sci-fi. Yet there was a flaw in my strategy. If the future is actually being made by sci-fi readers, ignorance of the genre may be a fatal blind spot.

A couple of weeks ago I had dinner in San Francisco with a bright young crypto crowd. Crypto is short for crypto-currency, which is the best known use for blockchain, or distributed ledger, technology. The most famous crypto-currency is bitcoin. Crypto is the cool thing these days. The cool people who were at Facebook when it was cool and who before that were at Google when it was cool are now into crypto.

Steering the conversation away from blockchain and towards my uncool comfort zone, I asked if crypto people still read books. Yes, of course, but mostly science fiction. Such as? Well, obviously, Snow Crash, my host replied, in the way that I might once have said: "Well, obviously, The Day of the Triffids" - or Fahrenheit 451 or A Clockwork Orange, which were my favourite works of sci-fi when I was a kid.

I'd never heard of Snow Crash because it was published in 1992, long after I kicked the sci-fi habit. It turns out that the novel - by the American author Neal Stephenson - was once required reading for new Facebook recruits. I've now read it. So should you. And so should all those senators and representatives who wasted two days last week asking Mark Zuckerberg questions that were either easy for him to answer or easy for him to duck.

Snow Crash is set in an unspecified but not too distant future, so perhaps around now, more than a quarter-century after its publication. As with all sci-fi, quite a bit of the predicted future hasn't come about (you guessed it: flying cars - still waiting). But an unusually large proportion has.

There are two worlds: reality and the Metaverse. Reality is a decaying, Balkanised America, a land in which the federal government has ceded much of its power to corporations, foreign interests ("Mr Lee's Greater Hong Kong") and organised crime. The rich inhabit fortified "burbclaves". The poor live in containers. The privatised highways are so clogged with traffic that deliveries are made by cyber-punks on skateboards. Everyone's armed to the teeth. There's even a character with a nuclear torpedo in his Harley-Davidson's sidecar.

The Metaverse, by contrast, is the next iteration of the internet: a multiplayer, virtual-reality mega-game populated by avatars, accessible through special goggles.

The defining characteristic of both worlds is that everybody's private information is readily available, not only to the CIC (Central Intelligence Corporation), the for-profit organisation formed by the CIA's merger with the Library of Congress, but also to whoever is willing to pay the CIC.

In other words, even if the highways of 2018 are not quite as Mad Max or Blade Runner as Stephenson imagined, much else about Snow Crash is eerily familiar. Globalisation having hollowed out most of the US economy, there are now "only four things we do better than anyone else: music, movies, microcode (software), high-speed pizza delivery".

With astounding prescience, Stephenson imagines not only virtual reality - those VR goggles now exist and are on sale from Facebook-owned Oculus - but also Google Earth: "a piece of CIC software called, simply, Earth . . . [used] to keep track of every bit of spatial information that it owns - all the maps, weather data, architectural plans and satellite surveillance stuff".

Artificial intelligence is here too. "For the most part I write myself," explains an automated online search engine. "That is, I have the innate ability to learn from experience. But this ability was originally coded into me by my creator."

The plot of Snow Crash hinges on the utter failure of the government to keep up with technology and the ability of bad actors to infect people's brains (not just their avatars) with malware.

The character of L Bob Rife personifies Big Tech unbound. "Y'know, watching government regulators trying to keep up with the world is my favourite sport. Remember when they busted up Ma Bell [as the US telephone monopoly used to be known]? . . . They were in the same business as me. The information business. Moving phone conversations around on little tiny copper wires, one at a time. Government busted them up - at the same time when I was starting cable TV franchises in thirty states. Haw! Can you believe that? It's like if they figured out a way to regulate horses at the same time the [Ford] Model T and the airplane were being introduced."

L Bob's dastardly masterplan is to infect the minds of all network users with Snow Crash, which is the mental equivalent of a complete hard-drive failure. (Stephenson got the idea when his early Apple Mac "crashed and wrote gibberish", producing "something that looked vaguely like static on a broken television set".)

What exactly is Snow Crash, asks the lead male character, Hiro Protagonist. "Is it a virus, a drug or a religion?"

"What's the difference?" replies his former girlfriend.

I'm not saying that Zuckerberg is L Bob Rife. Nor am I saying Facebook is the CIC. I am saying that the people who questioned Zuckerberg so ineffectually on Capitol Hill last week need to read Snow Crash. And maybe they also need to stop taking campaign contributions from Facebook. Since 2014 Facebook has contributed a total of $641,685 to all but 16 of the 105 members of Congress that Zuckerberg faced last week.

Senator Orrin Hatch (Republican): "How do you sustain a business model in which users don't pay for your service?"

Zuckerberg: "Senator, we run ads."

Senator Lindsey Graham (R): "You don't feel like you have a monopoly?"

Zuckerberg: "It certainly doesn't feel like that to me." [Laughter.]

Well, duh.

Here are four reasons why much tougher questions were warranted last week. If you ever signed up for Facebook, hundreds of advertisers have your contact information, and Facebook has your entire contacts list, not to mention a complete list of all the times you logged in, which device you used and where you were. If you are an Android user, Facebook also logs your call and text history. If you log off Facebook, it can still track your browsing activity. And even if you never signed up for Facebook, the company may still have a "shadow profile" of you.

"Congress is good at doing two things," Congressman Billy Long told Zuckerberg last week. "Doing nothing and overreacting." He forgot about regulating horses.

In my naivety I thought last week that the game was finally up for Facebook. Having effectively turned a blind eye to the antics of both the Russians and Cambridge Analytica, Zuckerberg seemed certain to be roasted alive. Instead we got the political equivalent of Snow Crash.Niall Ferguson is the Milbank Family senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, Stanford

D01Well-fundedbiotech startupis joining UA incubator asclient companyBiotech company estimated to have $17M economic impact on TucsonTucson, Ariz.FULL TEXT

The University of Arizona’s tech-oriented business incubator has remained active despite the challenges of COVID-19, recently adding two new companies including an intriguing, out-of-state “stealth” startup landed partly thanks to the pandemic.

The UA Center for Innovation last week announced that Techletics, a startup developing a mobile health app that helps people improve their posture, had joined its incubation program at the UA Tech Park on South Rita Road.

The UA incubator also recently announced that Nanomoneo, a biotech instrument startup backed by a Nevada venture-capital firm, had joined the program as one of more than 30 incubator clients.

In announcing Nanomoneo as a client company, the UA said only that the company is developing technology “that allow consumers to ‘see’ things that are not normally visible with the naked eye.”

But little else has been made public about what Nanomoneo is developing.

Nanomoneo president Juliann Talkington acknowledged the company, which is backed by Red Bear Venture of Incline Village, Nevada, is in “stealth” mode — an under-the-radar stance often used by very early stage companies to keep their technologies shielded until they are properly protected by patents, for example.

Talkington, a partner in Red Bear, said Nanomoneo will share more after it files for key patents, perhaps in six months or so, but until then she declined to discuss instrument technologies or specific products or markets, noting that the UA was privy to key details as part of its application process.

The UA has agreed to keep the information confidential, she added.

“Basically, what we’re working on are products that allow consumers and non-technical professionals to see things that are not normally visible to the naked eye,” she said. “Anything that somebody might want to see but can’t see, whether something in a solution or a solid.”

While Nanomoneo’s technology remains mostly a mystery for now, the company is well-funded by Red Bear, and is busy hiring, Talkington said.

The company plans to hire 14 people over the next five years, including research scientists, engineers and research support, with an estimated total economic impact of $17 million, according to the UA.

In Nanomoneo’s multi-state search for a launch site, Talkington said, Tucson stood out for the UACI and its offerings — including ample, and flexible wet and dry lab space and the ability to contract with the UA for the use of high-end research equipment.

She also gave high marks to Sun Corridor Inc., the Tucson-area economic development agency, and Tucson overall for its welcoming community.

“We evaluated a number of different places, and we were very impressed with Tucson, that’s why we’re here,” said Talkington, who has come to Tucson over the years to visit her parents. “We love Tucson, the people are super friendly here.”

Talkington said Nanomoneo also chose Tucson as part of a larger strategy by Red Bear to locate its startups in smaller, “second-tier” cities to avoid many of the disadvantages of big tech centers like San Francisco, New York, Seattle and Boston — including often stricter COVID-19 rules for labs and potentially disruptive street protests.

“There’s a lot of regulatory uncertainty in those markets and social unrest, both of which are hard to navigate for startups, she said. Talkington has managed several startups, including a medical-device company, for Red Bear Venture.

Now that Nanomoneao has found a supportive home, finding the talent it needs is a main concern for Talkington, The company is hiring Ph.D.-level research scientists and engineers with experience with sensors, programming, nanoparticles, and organic molecules.

The company has hired one research scientist and is in the process of hiring another, Talkington said.

To apply, send a resume and cover letter to amrtalk@nanomoneo.com, or use the company’s job posting on LinkedIn.

Nanomoneo also is looking to hire college and high school students as interns, Talkington said.

The company is taking internship applications from UA students at Handshake, an online platform that links college students to internships and jobs.

Meanwhile, Techletics is developing a patent-pending, mobile health application called MyPostureLife that uses the embedded sensors of a smartphone to track and improve posture — with no other additional device.

The founding members of Techletics are Nadav Gerson, CEO; Jan Halozan, chief technology officer; Mike Durham, chief strategy officer; and Nate McFall, chief marketing officer.

BIOSA SPONSORS OV INCUBATOR SPOT

In more news from UACI, the Biotechnology Industry Organization of Southern Arizona (BIOSA) will fund admission for one of the first members of its new biotech-focused incubator site in Oro Valley.

As winner of the “UACI Sponsored Launch Fueled by BIOSA” competition, one biotech startup company will receive a sponsored year’s admission at the UACI at Oro Valley.

Included with entrance into the incubator program and space at the new location, the startup will also be awarded a cash prize of $5,000. The total package value is $15,000 and funded by BIOSA.

Application submissions are open through Oct. 14. After a review and interview process, the winning team will be announced on Nov. 2.

For more information and to apply, visit tucne.ws/1ft4.

TECH EXPO GOES VIRTUAL

Like many other events, the Southern Arizona Tech + Business Expo is going online for its eighth annual edition on Oct. 7.

Sponsored by the Arizona Technology Council and the Arizona Commerce Authority, the daylong program will be held via VirBELA, an online collaboration platform.

The event will include a keynote speech by Roy Donelson of Raytheon Missiles & Defense and feature exhibitors in optics, biotech, mining, aviation, defense, robotics, aerospace and information technology.

The cost to attend is $20 for Tech Council members and $40 for non-members; preregistration and a software download is required. For more information or to register, go to tucne.ws/1ft5.

urn:contentItem:5TSN-RFS1-JCMN-Y22G-00000-00Well-Known Facts Can Hurt You2018-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisWell-Known Facts Can Hurt You

Nov 20, 2018( GuruFocus.com: http://www.gurufocus.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Our longtime readers are aware that we analyze the U.S. stock market through the prism of what we call 'well-known facts.' A well-known fact is a body of economic information which is pretty much known to all market participants and has been acted on by almost everyone with available capital. Former Intel (NASDAQ:INTC[1]) CEO Andy Grove use to say, 'when everyone knows something is so, nobody's knows nothin'.' Today there are several well-known facts that we believe are leading investors down a destructive path. Fact No. 1: Data mining and artificial intelligence will change the worldInvestors have been so jacked up about data mining and artificial intelligence that they have distorted nearly every major U.S. stock market sector.

Anybody who can walk while chewing gum knows that data mining and A.I. are in use, and the companies connected to it trade for 100 times profits (if they have any). The S...00 Index is loaded with tech stocks that would be at the heart of this phenomena, and Invesco is giving us nightmares with advertisements to invest in the QQQ exchange-traded fund. The QQQ is comprised of the 100 largest Nasdaq companies and gives a little purer heroin to tech-hungry buyers of the well-known fact. George Gilder, in his book, "Life After Google," argues that data mining and A.I. should begin to suffer from diminishing marginal utility going forward. Regardless of whether he is right or not, the price you pay to be on the data mining and A.I. train make five to 10-year investment success unlikely. Fact No. 2: Home building is driven by affordability This might be the dumbest well-known fact the markets have ever bought into. Investments do well when purchased at an affordable moment. Stocks were affordable in 2009. Most investors were afraid of them and nobody had an urge to manufacture new ones via initial public offerings (IPOS). In 2018, common stocks as a group are very unaffordable. Despite the lack of affordability, there are the most low-quality IPOs this year as any year in the last 20 (See chart below) [1]:The same is true in houses. Standalone residences were the most affordable to buy in 2011 as in any year of my adult life. We built 320,000 in the year 2011. They were the least affordable in the 1970s and 1980s, and we built one million homes many of those years with 65% of the existing population base. There is an inverse correlation between home building and affordability. Fact No. 3: Big tech will avoid antitrust scrutiny There is a well-known fact that goes like this: 'Since search, social media and e-commerce delivery is basically free and is benefitting the consumer, the public doesn't need to be protected from the anti-competitive behavior.' Under this flawed and very selfish logic, controlling 80% of the profits in advertising through social media or search is acceptable to the masses. Selling things online and delivering them at a loss to drive traffic to your cloud business seems to be fine with those who aren't worried about the massive long-term dislocation it could cause in our economy. In the eyes of the kings and queens of tech, as long as they conquer the world, it is the job of our ever-inflated U.S. government bureaucracy to take care of everyone dislocated by these anticompetitive activities. The fallout from this well-known fact is all over the news. Facebook (NASDAQ:FB[2]) has used its monopoly in social media to brainwash the masses, violate the public's long-lost privacy and then claim to not have had any idea what they were doing. In effect, we are a nation of Ed Saverins, the buddy of Facebook's CEO who almost got swindled out of his share of the company. He had to go to court and so will the public to right the wrong. Alphabet's (NASDAQ:GOOG[3]) Google gets 80% of the profits in search and arguably knows more about you than your spouse or the federal government. They control your privacy and shut out competitors in every non-search business in which they operate. Expedia's (EXPE) largest expense item is Google advertising and their biggest competitor is Google themselves. I'm sure Google never uses what they know about Expedia to do more in travel commissions each year than Expedia does. Amazon has a massive market share in e-commerce and in cloud services, which we mentioned is not mutually exclusive. We assume their e-commerce business is among the nation's three largest users of the cloud (pornography, Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX[4]) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN[5]) e-commerce). Therefore, who can compete in e-commerce when someone like Amazon can lose money on most deliveries? Amazon's AWS division gets a cut of each dollar of e-commerce revenue. The Wall Street Journal has weighed in on the activities of these three companies as follows: 'U.S. tech companies are increasingly facing a backlash from consumers, businesses and politicians about the widespread exploitation of personal data. In Europe the regulatory remediation has gone further, but action in the U.S. seems inevitable too.' [2] Fact No. 4: There is a recession out there which will hurt Main Street From 2000 to 2003, we had a recession in the U.S. when the dot-com technology bubble broke. We could do that again, but every region built around tech suffered while the rest of the country enjoyed continued economic growth. We believe a curse surrounds the expensive coastal cities and market readers are confusing a needed correction in Seattle, San Francisco, Boston, New York and Miami, with a national residential real estate correction. There is no correlation between affordability and home building in the last 60 years (see chart below) [3]: https://static.seekingalpha.com/uploads/2018/11/20/414172-15427371031943102_origin.png We believe the economy of the U.S. will be about what Steve Case calls, 'The Rise of the Rest.' Tech employees who see their parent company's stock decline will ask to move to affordable areas of the country where water and Wi-Fi are inexpensive and readily available. The well-known fact is that millennials want to be in the coastal cities even after they marry and have kids. Eventually, their stagnant paychecks and the need to own a home will send them elsewhere in the country. Home building will boom in the other 85% of the places people in America live. Welcome to the next big thing, a huge intra-country migration to the flyover states. In conclusion, we think the stock market is loaded with well-known facts and these facts are there to be taken advantage of by discerning, patient and long-duration investors! We are grateful for your attention and hope you all have a great Thanksgiving holiday. [1] The Wall Street Journal (IPO Market Has Never Been This Forgiving to Money-Losing Firms[6]). urn:contentItem:5W54-1M71-DY19-C35C-00000-00Well-meaning governments must be wary of playing big tech's PR game2019-05-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisWell-meaning governments must be wary of playing big tech's PR gamePaul Smith

Facebook et al had a huge PR win last week when NZ PM Jacinda Ardern's Christchurch Call let them pretend they can be left alone to fix their own problems.

When news of US tech giants joining forces in an "unprecedented push against the sharing of terrorist content" hit front pages of Australian newspapers last week, readers could realistically have been left with the assumption that Facebook et al were finally making wholesale changes to smarten up their act, after the nadir of broadcasting the Christchurch terror shootings to the world.

The trouble is, that is just not reality ... it was simply what they wanted everyone to think, because they know the court of public (and therefore government) opinion is firmly against them.

Reading through last week's "Christchurch call" showed that, aside from the kind of controls and initiatives you would expect global media platforms to be doing anyway, there were no new commitments of any significance at all.

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and French President Emmanuel Macron are trying to do the right thing by seeking to publicly call out the need for changes regarding violent content, but unfortunately last week's announcement made them pawns in what was essentially a huge PR victory for the likes of Facebook and Google.

The fact that Facebook flaks were contacting journalists in advance to try to secure pre-briefed coverage of the announcement, showed how desperate the company is to be praised for seeking solutions to an outrage it facilitated.

Good intentions ring hollow

Both Facebook and Google are embroiled in a much broader debate about their negative impact on society and business at large, and the live-streaming press event should be framed in the context of ongoing questions about how heavily they can and should be regulated.

The default position for big tech in this conversation, of course, is "as lightly as possible", as they hope governments can be convinced to trust them to fix problems by themselves.

But politicians must not be fooled by grand statements of good intent from companies that have consistently pushed the boundaries of acceptable conduct.

In many areas, other than just terrorist content, these same companies have only moved to do the right thing once external outrage forced them to do so.

Anyone who has followed the quite ludicrous litany of scandals befalling Facebook in recent times knows that Mark Zuckerberg probably has a global copyright on the words "we must do better", and has a well-worn playbook of apologising profusely for horrifying the world before riding out the storms untouched.

What we got last week was little more than theatre.

Facebook and   its peers pledged to update their T&Cs to say you aren't allowed to share terrorist content; to make it easier to flag horrible content for removal; that they will "continue" to invest in tech to help spot nasty content; and that they will identify some appropriate checks and balances on live-streaming at some point in the future.

They should be doing all of that as a bare minimum, and pledging to do so shouldn't save it from legislation.

Facebook in particular is massively in deficit when it comes to earned trust, and it is time for laws, rather than unenforceable codes of conduct, to make it to do the right thing.

University of Technology Sydney postdoctoral research fellow Sacha Molitorisz believes the Australian competition regulator got it right last year when it proposed regulating Facebook and Google in the same way as traditional media companies.

It is anyone's guess just how influential social-media-spread falsehoods were in shaping last weekend's federal election for example, but it is without question that the platforms allowed fanciful and deliberately misleading content to be consumed by many punters, without any sense that the distributor had a duty towards editorial control.

The ACCC proposed the creation of "clear guiding principles for an overarching platform-neutral regulatory regime that can apply effectively across media formats and platforms, with common rules applying to online and offline activities, and which is adaptable to new services, platforms and technologies".

Molitorisz says this would be a great starting point for a broader review of how to regulate digital platforms.

"Currently, digital platforms are largely unregulated, whereas traditional media are subject to a confusing lot of industry codes and regulation," he says.

"The ACCC's recommendation doesn't offer a quick fix, but is a good start for providing a comprehensive, long-term solution in a complicated media landscape.

"Ultimately we need to answer the questions of how to categorise digital platforms, how to regulate them and how to hold them accountable."

Powerful media monopolies

As his UTS colleague, distinguished professor of public communication Jim Macnamara, said last week, the problem with advocating legislation is in the global nature of platforms.

Some kind of co-ordination across international boundaries is going to be required if governments are going to be able to elicit anything more than fresh sincere-sounding apologies, the next time one of the big platforms does something wrong.

"For a hundred years there have been concerns about media monopolies, because when media gets so much power it can cause a huge amount of damage if it is not wielded responsibly," Macnamara says.

"In the last decades the likes of Facebook, Google, Amazon and YouTube have become big powerful media monopolies and they need to take some level of responsibility as major media, like regulated TV broadcasters have had to."

Ms Ardern has made it clear that she views the Christchurch Call as a different topic to policing social networks for fake news, and to be fair she did suggest that it was a start, rather than an end point to the challenge of tackling violent content.

However, history suggests it will be the end of it, and that the tech giants will just continue with their policies of "breaking things", unless strong actions follow the nice words.

urn:contentItem:5W54-1RM1-JD34-V04G-00000-00Well-meaning leaders must be wary of social media's PR game2019-05-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSPg. 21Well-meaning leaders must be wary of social media's PR gamePaul Smith

When news of US tech giants joining forces in an "unprecedented push against the sharing of terrorist content" hit front pages of Australian newspapers last week, readers could realistically have been left with the assumption that Facebook et al were finally making wholesale changes to smarten up their act, after the nadir of broadcasting the Christchurch terror shootings to the world.

The trouble is, that is just not reality ... it was simply what they wanted everyone to think, because they know the court of public (and therefore government) opinion is firmly against them.

Reading through last week's "Christchurch call" showed that, aside from the kind of controls and initiatives you would expect global media platforms to be doing anyway, there were no new commitments of any significance at all.

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and French President Emmanuel Macron are trying to do the right thing by seeking to publicly call out the need for changes regarding violent content, but unfortunately last week's announcement made them pawns in what was essentially a huge PR victory for the likes of Facebook and Google.

The fact that Facebook flaks were contacting journalists in advance to try to secure pre-briefed coverage of the announcement showed how desperate the company is to be praised for seeking solutions to an outrage it facilitated.

Both Facebook and Google are embroiled in a much broader debate about their negative impact on society and business at large, and the live-streaming press event should be framed in the context of ongoing questions about how heavily they can and should be regulated.

The default position for big tech in this conversation, of course, is "as lightly as possible", as they hope governments can be convinced to trust them to fix problems by themselves.

But politicians must not be fooled by grand statements of good intent from companies that have consistently pushed the boundaries of acceptable conduct. In many areas, other than just terrorist content, these same companies have only moved to do the right thing once external outrage forced them to do so.

Anyone who has followed the quite ludicrous litany of scandals befalling Facebook in recent times knows that Mark Zuckerberg probably has a global copyright on the words "we must do better", and has a well-worn playbook of apologising profusely for horrifying the world before riding out the storms untouched.

What we got last week was little more than theatre.

Facebook and its peers pledged to update their T&Cs to say you aren't allowed to share terrorist content; to make it easier to flag horrible content for removal; that they will "continue" to invest in tech to help spot nasty content; and that they will identify some appropriate checks and balances on live-streaming at some point in the future. They should be doing all of that as a bare minimum, and pledging to do so shouldn't save it from legislation.

Facebook in particular is massively in deficit when it comes to earned trust, and it is time for laws, rather than unenforceable codes of conduct, to make it do the right thing.

University of Technology Sydney postdoctoral research fellow Sacha Molitorisz believes the Australian competition regulator got it right last year when it proposed regulating Facebook and Google in the same way as traditional media companies.

It is anyone's guess just how influential social-media-spread falsehoods were in shaping last weekend's federal election, for example, but it is without question that the platforms allowed fanciful and deliberately misleading content to be consumed by many punters, without any sense that the distributor had a duty towards editorial control.

The ACCC proposed the creation of "clear guiding principles for an overarching platform-neutral regulatory regime that can apply effectively across media formats and platforms, with common rules applying to online and offline activities, and which is adaptable to new services, platforms and technologies".

Molitorisz says this would be a great starting point for a broader review of how to regulate digital platforms.

"Currently, digital platforms are largely unregulated, whereas traditional media are subject to a confusing lot of industry codes and regulation," he says. "The ACCC's recommendation doesn't offer a quick fix, but is a good start for providing a comprehensive, long-term solution in a complicated media landscape.

"Ultimately we need to answer the questions of how to categorise digital platforms, how to regulate them and how to hold them accountable."

As his UTS colleague, distinguished professor of public communication Jim Macnamara, said last week, the problem with advocating legislation is in the global nature of platforms.

Some kind of co-ordination across international boundaries is going to be required if governments are going to be able to elicit anything more than fresh sincere-sounding apologies, the next time one of the big platforms does something wrong.

"For a hundred years there have been concerns about media monopolies, because when media gets so much power it can cause a huge amount of damage if it is not wielded responsibly," Macnamara says. "In the last decades the likes of Facebook, Google, Amazon and YouTube have become big, powerful media monopolies and they need to take some level of responsibility as major media, like regulated TV broadcasters have had to."

Ms Ardern has made clear she views the Christchurch Call as a different topic to policing social networks for fake news, and to be fair she did suggest it was a start, not an end to the challenge of tackling violent content.

However, history suggests it will be the end of it, and that the tech giants will just continue with their policies of "breaking things", unless strong actions follow the nice words.

urn:contentItem:5SV7-PBB1-JBVM-Y2X7-00000-00WE'LL REGULATE FACEBOOK IF LEO WON'T, VOWS FF;Party pledges to force through law creating social media regulatorWe must bring tech giants to heel2018-07-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1,4,5WE'LL REGULATE FACEBOOK IF LEO WON'T, VOWS FFParty pledges to force through law creating social media regulatorWe must bring tech giants to heelEmma Jane Hade

FIANNA FÁIL is ready to force through the creation of the social media regulator that Leo Varadkar has tried to shelve.

The party is preparing legislation to create the new watchdog - and is ready to join forces with other Opposition TDs to push the appointment through the Oireachtas.

FF Communications spokesman Timmy Dooley said his party's Bill would give the new social media regulator 'very substantial powers ... to regulate and police the industry'. There would also be 'very significant financial penalties'. The regulator's office would be similar to the Office of the Digital Safety Commissioner that Denis Naughten had, in January, promised would be established this year. But the Taoiseach is refusing to commit to it. Fianna Fáil will introduce its social media regulator Bill after the Dáil's summer recess.

The establishment of such an office will be one of a number of issues discussed with the Government in the upcoming Budget negotiations to ensure the money is there to fund it, said Mr Dooley.

The Government's target of an Office of the Digital Safety Commissioner for later this year was abandoned when ministers launched their coolly received Action Plan for Online Safety last week.

The Government said that setting up the office was more complex than expected and would require international cooperation.

But now Mr Dooley has said Fianna Fáil will push the plan ahead amid demands for such an office by child safety groups horrified by the revelations about Facebook on Channel 4's Dispatches.

With a similar Bill to create a Digital Safety Commissioner having already been introduced by Sinn Féin - and the Labour Party and Social Democrats demanding such an office too - the Government is facing a surefire defeat in the Dáil on the issue.

Mr Dooley said that while Fianna Fáil supports the principles of Sinn Féin's Bill to establish a Digital Safety Commissioner, the party does not believe it goes far enough as it does not outline the financial penalties needed to bring 'those people to heel'.

Sinn Féin's Bill is based on a Law Reform Commission recommendation but Mr Dooley said his party wants to strengthen the watchdog so it can hit firms with substantial financial penalties if they are found in breach of the independent watchdog's rules.

he said.: 'We agree with the principles, He said: 'We agree with the principles, but it doesn't go far enough in terms of setting out fines and penalties.' The Fianna Fáil Bill would establish the office of a social media regulator and give them 'very substantial powers to develop a regulatory regime which is appropriate, and then to regulate and police the industry'. 'And then to have available to them very significant financial penalties for failure to respect the independent rules that will be established by that office.' Fianna Fáil is still working on its Bill but says these penalties would be a percentage of the social media company's turnover.

This is similar to what the European Commission does when it sanctions companies. 'They base it on percentage of turnover,' Mr Dooley said.

Minimum limits will be set but these fines could have the potential to run into the 'multiples of millions'.

The Sinn Féin Bill to establish a Digital Safety Commissioner passed the second of five stages in the Dáil earlier this year and is to go to committee stage after the summer recess.

Mr Dooley said if that Bill reaches committee stage before Fianna Fáil has the opportunity to introduce its own proposals to the House, Fianna Fáil would table amendments to the Sinn Féin proposal so the office had the power to impose 'very significant fines and sanctions'.

'So we will either introduce our own, or bring forward amendments to that [Sinn Féin] Bill.' The pledge to force through a social media regulator comes after the Channel 4 Dispatches documentary showed Facebook moderators allowing videos of child assaults, bullying, animal cruelty and self-harm to remain on its site.

The Government has flipflopped on the establishment of a Digital Safety Commissioner here in recent months.

Taoiseach Leo Varadkar said last week he believed social media companies are mostly doing a good job of regulating their sites.

'I think, in fairness to the big tech companies that are active online, any time I meet them, they are very in tune to this issue.' On Wednesday, the Taoiseach described the Channel 4 documentary's findings as 'shocking and most unacceptable'. While he suggested the Government would examine whether 'legislative mechanisms' would allow a system of fines to be brought in, he stopped short of committing the Government to doing so or to recommencing the plan to create a Digital Safety Commissioner's Office.

Seán Sherlock, Labour's justice spokesman, yesterday reiterated his call to the Government to proceed with the appointment of a Digital Safety Commissioner.

He told RTÉ Radio: 'This is something that [Mr Naughten] promised in January of this year.

'They subsequently announced the Action Plan for Online Safety last week and he rowed back on that promise, and there is no mention to any great extent of a Digital Safety Commissioner.

'I think he needs to take that on board now. I think we need to provide for the regulation of the online space now.' Several figures from children's charities and organisations also backed these calls, and Tanya Ward of the Children's Rights Alliance said: 'I think the Channel 4 programme proves the reason we need a Digital Safety Commissioner.' Communications Minister Denis Naughten was due to meet Facebook chiefs in New York last night to discuss the scandal.

One source said last night: 'Everyone wants him to put it up to Facebook, but that is just not going to happen.

'They employ too many people and their growing presence in Ireland is just too important to want to be the man who puts that into doubt.

'However, he is going to have to at least go through the motions and ask the odd difficult question. He is also going to have to seek assurances.' After the Dispatches investigation, Mr Naughten said he is 'deeply concerned' about the revelations. He said: 'The programme… raises serious questions for the company in respect of the manner in which it handles reports of harmful or illegal content carried on its platform.' Mr Naughten also said it raises questions about the way it moderates content. He said: 'Clearly Facebook has failed to meet the standards the public rightly expects of it'.

urn:contentItem:5P51-80X1-DXH2-64W7-00000-00Wells Fargo Asset Mgmt`s John Manley Intvd on Blmbg Radio2017-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE7:00 AM ESTJohn ManleyNEWSInternational073186cb.556Wells Fargo Asset Mgmt`s John Manley Intvd on Blmbg RadioDavid Gura, Francine Lacqua

Discussion on earnings and business.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG RADIO

JULY 31, 2017

SPEAKERS: JOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT

DAVID GURA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] GURA: John Manley joins us now here in our Bloomberg 1130 studio. He's the Chief Equity Strategist at Wells Fargo Funds. And, John, great to have you with us here in the middle of earning seasons, squarely in the middle of the second quarter earning season.

Let's take stock of where we are as the big tech companies reporting last week, some financial companies reporting as well. Just give us the lay of the land as you see it as these results to continue to come in.

MANLEY: All the way from benign to good. I think the numbers are coming in pretty well. The revenue numbers are starting to surprise, which is sort of interesting. And this is giving large to something that a lot of people thought that profits were so high, they couldn't go higher even if the economy got better.

Well, the revenues, Tom, we were seeing a better economy and the profit numbers are just what they. They're saying things are getting better.

LACQUA: Yes. But, John, at the same, a lot of these aren't cost cuts. I know the revenue is a strong kind of indication that things are getting better. But what if we were loved in a false sense of security because it's all cost cuts and not actual growth?

MANLEY: Any sense of security in the stock market is a false sense of security. Of course, we have done this long this long enough. But ultimately, it will prove me false.

However, what you're seeing are just early stages. Ideally, what corporation should do is make themselves into very, very efficient machines. And that's what they've done. And then build it that way and the economy will come. This is the United States over here. We still have -- I wouldn't call pens up to me. We have natural exam.

People came to the United States. Our ancestors came from the United States to have more. We're willing to work for it in most cases. And I think what happens is we put the problems 10 years ago further and further behind us. And yes, a little bit of stimulation from the fed. You get yourself a pretty decent economy. And if that happens that just poured over an efficient machine, I mean, profits come out of it.

LACQUA: Is it really only a little bit of stimulus from the fed? What happens if they actually move too quickly? I mean, they telegraphed, right, that they are starting to normalize. But what happens if companies are not ready for it?

MANLEY: They'll stop -- they'll stop doing it. One of the things that I have a chat (ph), you know, says a few weeks ago was that she gets - - she's aware. She knows there's a risk in stimulating too quickly or not stimulating enough. She knows there's a risk in how they unwind the balance sheet. She knows the risk of inflation. She knows the risk of deflation.

Now, she may not know exactly the road or the path to follow down on the way to recovery, but she knows to look for any misstep on her part. Anything she's done that possibly could derail. So, I guess what I can say about Janet Yellen is sure, she may be wrong but she won't be wrong for long and that's really what matters to the markets.

GURA: John, what's your sense of the degree to which this Fed Reserve, this Federal Open Market Committee is paying attention to the market? How big a concern is that for them?

MANLEY: I think they read the papers and, obviously, they listen to some very good radio broadcast from time to time. They have to be aware. I mean, you know, it's like asking your doctor did he read the thermometer after he test you.

We're pretty didn't care to what's going on. We're not perfect. We bounce around in awful lot. But we're pretty good in here.

And now, I think it's also important to remember, the fed and the capital markets and the economy are linked, because when the fed wants to push money at the economy, it goes through us first. So then let's think of it as a pipe carrying out, in or out of the economy. They sort of look at us, they get an obvious sign as money headed the right direction And, you know, they see a meltdown in stock market a little bit, they know that's can't be good for the rest of the real world.

The same thing is true for housing and a few others things. Look at what wealth is doing. If wealth is being created or at least maintained, they've got to feel reasonably comfortable.

GURA: And look at the soft data, you look the surveys, how businesses feel, their willingness to hire, their willingness to expand. And it seems like there is still a gap between the soft data and the hard data.

As you look at these earnings reports, what's the sense that you have of when the two are going to meet? Where we're going to see companies try to invest more in CAPEX?

MANLEY: I think you're starting to see -- I think what you have to realize too is that when -- it probably happen quickly because we're still on a fairly competitive landscape. And so far, it's been better for corporations who are competing against other corporations to buyback shares, to reinvest in their businesses by buying into their businesses. That doesn't have capacity obviously.

But at some point in time, it's not because the companies want to do it, it's because their consumers are demanding more of their products. If you and I are competing and I see you beginning to pick up share because you expand a little bit, watch out quickly, I would start my CAPEX of them.

LACQUA: John, are market merger is good for evaluations or bad?

MANLEY: Well, it depends on merger it has.

LACQUA: I know, in the industry, but -- because, you know, in general, just full of desperation.

MANLEY: I think that merge is to create synergy without being tremendously destructive to jobs, to create more efficient, more logical corporations are generally good. You don't want restraining the trade. I don't want restraining the trade. You do want efficiencies. You do want logical structures to a degree they foster that, I think it's fine. You just always keep your eyes open. There's nothing wrong with regulation. It's just got to be done, you know, a fair, even-handed way.

LACQUA: John, you know, we went into 2017, looking at Brexit, looking at President Trump. And there was this wave of anti-populism of -- or populism anti-globalization. Should that do anything to stock markets?

MANLEY: Well, it hasn't. I mean, there's an old saying, expect the worse and you'll never be disappointed. And the things to market has not been disappointed this year.

To me, it is a business where you have rising demand, you have rising supply of things that can be done, and you have an electoral process. Let's people vote themselves into healthcare.

Health care is percent of GDP, I think, must or will have to rise. That's my opinion.

LACQUA: John, pretty quickly. Are you concerned about China? We seem to be in the benign belief that China is fine. What if it were and what is that do to U.S. stocks?

MANLEY: That's a lot of problems. And we still want to get too close to the Yellow River. That happened before I was born. Nothing good comes with that. Again, we have some slowly here -- the North Korean/China situation is one of the unknowables out there. And it is a big disconcerting at this point in time. It's heating up.

My guess is, is if we do anything, it will be decisive and very quick but you'll never know about these things as it's just the risk that you just have to live with the time being.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much just for joining us. He is John Manley and he is a Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo Asset Management.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

JOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG RADIO

JULY 31, 2017

SPEAKERS: JOHN MANLEY, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ASSET MANAGEMENT

DAVID GURA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] GURA: John Manley joins us now here in our Bloomberg 1130 studio. He's the Chief Equity Strategist at Wells Fargo Funds. And, John, great to have you with us here in the middle of earning seasons, squarely in the middle of the second quarter earning season.

Let's take stock of where we are as the big tech companies reporting last week, some financial companies reporting as well. Just give us the lay of the land as you see it as these results to continue to come in.

MANLEY: All the way from benign to good. I think the numbers are coming in pretty well. The revenue numbers are starting to surprise, which is sort of interesting. And this is giving large to something that a lot of people thought that profits were so high, they couldn't go higher even if the economy got better.

Well, the revenues, Tom, we were seeing a better economy and the profit numbers are just what they. They're saying things are getting better.

LACQUA: Yes. But, John, at the same, a lot of these aren't cost cuts. I know the revenue is a strong kind of indication that things are getting better. But what if we were loved in a false sense of security because it's all cost cuts and not actual growth?

MANLEY: Any sense of security in the stock market is a false sense of security. Of course, we have done this long this long enough. But ultimately, it will prove me false.

However, what you're seeing are just early stages. Ideally, what corporation should do is make themselves into very, very efficient machines. And that's what they've done. And then build it that way and the economy will come. This is the United States over here. We still have -- I wouldn't call pens up to me. We have natural exam.

People came to the United States. Our ancestors came from the United States to have more. We're willing to work for it in most cases. And I think what happens is we put the problems 10 years ago further and further behind us. And yes, a little bit of stimulation from the fed. You get yourself a pretty decent economy. And if that happens that just poured over an efficient machine, I mean, profits come out of it.

LACQUA: Is it really only a little bit of stimulus from the fed? What happens if they actually move too quickly? I mean, they telegraphed, right, that they are starting to normalize. But what happens if companies are not ready for it?

MANLEY: They'll stop -- they'll stop doing it. One of the things that I have a chat (ph), you know, says a few weeks ago was that she gets - - she's aware. She knows there's a risk in stimulating too quickly or not stimulating enough. She knows there's a risk in how they unwind the balance sheet. She knows the risk of inflation. She knows the risk of deflation.

Now, she may not know exactly the road or the path to follow down on the way to recovery, but she knows to look for any misstep on her part. Anything she's done that possibly could derail. So, I guess what I can say about Janet Yellen is sure, she may be wrong but she won't be wrong for long and that's really what matters to the markets.

GURA: John, what's your sense of the degree to which this Fed Reserve, this Federal Open Market Committee is paying attention to the market? How big a concern is that for them?

MANLEY: I think they read the papers and, obviously, they listen to some very good radio broadcast from time to time. They have to be aware. I mean, you know, it's like asking your doctor did he read the thermometer after he test you.

We're pretty didn't care to what's going on. We're not perfect. We bounce around in awful lot. But we're pretty good in here.

And now, I think it's also important to remember, the fed and the capital markets and the economy are linked, because when the fed wants to push money at the economy, it goes through us first. So then let's think of it as a pipe carrying out, in or out of the economy. They sort of look at us, they get an obvious sign as money headed the right direction And, you know, they see a meltdown in stock market a little bit, they know that's can't be good for the rest of the real world.

The same thing is true for housing and a few others things. Look at what wealth is doing. If wealth is being created or at least maintained, they've got to feel reasonably comfortable.

GURA: And look at the soft data, you look the surveys, how businesses feel, their willingness to hire, their willingness to expand. And it seems like there is still a gap between the soft data and the hard data.

As you look at these earnings reports, what's the sense that you have of when the two are going to meet? Where we're going to see companies try to invest more in CAPEX?

MANLEY: I think you're starting to see -- I think what you have to realize too is that when -- it probably happen quickly because we're still on a fairly competitive landscape. And so far, it's been better for corporations who are competing against other corporations to buyback shares, to reinvest in their businesses by buying into their businesses. That doesn't have capacity obviously.

But at some point in time, it's not because the companies want to do it, it's because their consumers are demanding more of their products. If you and I are competing and I see you beginning to pick up share because you expand a little bit, watch out quickly, I would start my CAPEX of them.

LACQUA: John, are market merger is good for evaluations or bad?

MANLEY: Well, it depends on merger it has.

LACQUA: I know, in the industry, but -- because, you know, in general, just full of desperation.

MANLEY: I think that merge is to create synergy without being tremendously destructive to jobs, to create more efficient, more logical corporations are generally good. You don't want restraining the trade. I don't want restraining the trade. You do want efficiencies. You do want logical structures to a degree they foster that, I think it's fine. You just always keep your eyes open. There's nothing wrong with regulation. It's just got to be done, you know, a fair, even-handed way.

LACQUA: John, you know, we went into 2017, looking at Brexit, looking at President Trump. And there was this wave of anti-populism of -- or populism anti-globalization. Should that do anything to stock markets?

MANLEY: Well, it hasn't. I mean, there's an old saying, expect the worse and you'll never be disappointed. And the things to market has not been disappointed this year.

People talk about the lack of downside volatility. The only explanation for that is there have been non-negative surprises or any consequence. Well, so many negative things that come out of Washington or (inaudible) or even Berlin or Paris, how can one say there aren't negative surprises? Of course, there are negative.

Well, the thing is it's not a surprise. I think investors have a fairly low expectation, maybe a very low expectation of what comes out of Washington or Berlin or Britain. And I think in that respect, it's going to be pretty hard to disappoint us.]

GURA: Let me ask about financials in particular. A number of banks have reported already. How enthusiastic are you about financial stocks at this point? And how radically have they sort of trigged around from where we're a few years back?

MANLEY: Well, 40 years ago, I made choices from my life amongst them, so --

GURA: Yes.

MANLEY: -- we're very intimate with financial stocks and financial corporations and all the big -- it can be the best business and the worst business in the world. And believe me, I've seen both.

I think what you have to look for is reasonable regulation. There is no way that banks or financial institutions should be wide open. On the other hand, regulation go too far. You look for just the amount of regulation that seems to be moving in the right direction.

Interest rates also have corporations when they're facing very, very low rates, have a very difficult time placing fees on things that should have fees on them. If that's the case, their earnings power is being starved. Higher rates to a degree, it doesn't represent real fed tightening allows financial corporations to charge those fees, right adjustable fees that tends to improve their profitability. I think that part still in front of them.

GURA: Let me ask you how much personality matters. We spent some time this morning on television talking about Stuart Gulliver who is outgoing head of HSBC. You look at who's heading up these banks now. You can say few more years left and a lot of these guys who are running these banks. And how worried are you about transition? How much do you associate performances, the big bangs in particular with the men, largely men who are running those companies?

MANLEY: That's really good question. I don't know the straight answer I can give you. I think a character. When I invest my money over the long term, I know I can't possibly know what's going to happen in 5, 10 years. But I can look at the corporate culture, I guess that's where giving else. A good corporate culture should have depth, strong managers, truly strong managers, shouldn't be afraid of having people alongside them from replacing. That's the whole idea.

And I think that's a good way to buy stocks. You might want to find a good industry. But find a good industry that's being run by good men and women, who bring up good men and women internally. And I think you have -- it could be a fair of good investment.

LACQUA: And so, you have that in financials done or are you just talking about another industry?

MANLEY: We're talking industries in general and some financials --

LACQUA: Right.

MANLEY: I'm not assuming bad that I don't believe you.

LACQUA: OK. So which industries do you think are doing better in terms of succession but also, you know, having fewer legacy issues?

MANLEY: Well, the fundamentals were -- I think the fundamentals will come through. I think health care is a great sort of hard (ph) parts had collision between an Asian population like myself, improving health care, technology, and representative markers that can vote the money towards the people who need it.

I think technology, which we've been talking about, business to business technology, I think you're going to see wage pressures in the next few years. And the only way to cheapskates around corporations are going to let that go through is that they can prove productivity somehow, and that means spending on technology.

We mentioned financials, and for sure down in our value, I still think, well it was pretty good place to be. I'm focused on the big high quality large paying dividend stocks in the oil industry.

LACQUA: And those are mainly, which ones?

MANLEY: Well, I can't name them.

LACQUA: No, I know you can't. But is it -- on which end, is it refinery or is it actually downstream?

MANLEY: Well, the ones that are integrated, say a little bit of both.

LACQUA: All right.

GURA: We'll leave it there, John Manley. We'll come back with John Manley here in a just a moment. Maybe talk a bit more about Washington, its effects on policy, a little bit more on central banking as well. John Manley, Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo joining us here on Bloomberg 1130 studios on Bloomberg Surveillance.

(BREAK)

GURA: David Gura and Francine Lacqua, Tom Keene off today. This is Bloomberg Surveillance on Bloomberg Radio. Brought to you by Invesco for concise market and economic insights, delivered to your inbox weekly, count on Invesco Global Market Strategist, Kristina Hooper, invesco.com/hooper to learn more.

Continuing our conversation here with John Manley, Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo Funds. And, John, let me just ask you about what we're seeing play out in Washington, D.C. The result of this optimism after the election after the inauguration, safe to say, some of that is anticipated. Why are we not seeing more of a market move as a result of that?

MANLEY: Well, fundamentals are getting better. I mean that -- ex Washington, you're seeing earnings expectations arise after a long period of time where they really went nowhere. Also, the fed is being beneficial I guess is the right word. The fed is being very careful about what they do there. Shown very, very strong high levels of awareness about what they do. And the valuations aren't that bad.

I think the -- how shall I put this? The intricacies of Donald Trump presidency were probably discounted the first 12 hours as president-elect. And after that, we probably didn't have much expectation. We may say things but I don't think we really believed or counted on him. So hence, no negative surprises.

GURA: How about the fed's balance sheet? We've got more detail from the fed on how that's going to unfold, when it does begin to unfold the last meeting relatively soon. It was the watch phrase that came out of the statement following it. How that's that going to play out in your world? How that's going to play in the equities space in particular?

MANLEY: Well, it's a risk and therefore I think it proceed slowly. Jenny Donell (ph) was on recently saying, you know, we don't really know exactly how this is going to play because we've never done something like this before. What does a wise person, what does a wise man or woman do when they're in an unknown territory? They move slowly and carefully and they check every step they make. And I think that's what's going to happen. I think a lot of lessons from the real world are going to be applied in the financial world.

No guarantees right. Maybe these are undoable but I think a lot of things that were supposedly undoable have gotten done in the last few years. So, I think this -- it will work. I'm optimistic. I think the fed will be very, very careful in how they proceed.

LACQUA: What do you mean by lessons, John? So, you're talking about lessons from the real world being transferred in the financial world.

MANLEY: Well, I mean -- I'm just taking at -- act the way you would in real life. If you're on a dark path and you don't know where you are, you don't take big steps, you take small steps and check your footing every single step along the way. That's what Janet Yellen will do the financial code (ph) enough in my opinion.

LACQUA: Right. But the problem is that then financial stocks are always on notaire, right? They're going from record high to record high. What about then pausing and having a look right, left and center?

MANLEY: Sure. I mean I think that's possible. I've learned enough to -- since I can't really predict 5 percent or 10 percent pullbacks with any sort of accuracy, I just sort of assumed they're a part, they're a cost of earning equities for the long term. I think it's a worthwhile cost which I think equities and the delivers as pure return over a long period of time to very patient investors.

But you cannot expect to know every little wiggle and twist is going to be. So it could easily be a 5 percent correction because of something that goes slightly wrong, a 10 percent correction. But I think it will be done right at the end of the day. And when it's done right, there's a lot of room for these stocks to be meaningfully higher.

GURA: John Manley, we've talked about financials a few minutes ago. Let me ask about a couple of other sectors. I'll start with technology. When you look at tech with large, do you think that it's fairly valued right now?

MANLEY: If I understood half of it, I'd probably say it was fairly -- you know, the really big ones are really expensive ones --

GURA: Yes.

MANLEY: -- there's a lesson to those. I learned this back in the late '90s. The valuations may be frightening. The valuations maybe frightening but evaluations at the end of the day isn't what's it. The valuations will not tell you. They may win you.

Every time I've seen a highly valued, high growth country or company or industry blow up solely because valuation, it was like watching a man fall down and up escalator. You may fall but you get pulled harder, almost always buying opportunities. And I saw that to the late '90s.

And it's because the surprise is -- if stock goes down and the earnings expectations go up, you sort of have a correction double click in the stock. All right, it was ahead of itself is now 30 percent cheaper. People buy into it. You go tweet this a few times. People become less ordered by valuations.

So, watch valuations always they can trip you up but I don't think it's more than a trip. Focus, I would say, on the business to business -- the real spending in tech over the next several years is going to be by business to make their workers more productive so they can pay them more.

GURA: And thank you very much there would be escalated. Let me ask you lastly about health care. We're a point where the government -- where the administration is evaluating whether or not to continue with a subsidies on some levels of insurance. Obviously, had the big debate over health care. Your keen on health care overall, when you look at this as a sector?

MANLEY: Right. You know, falling down and not escalate naturally leads to health care, I would say. Yes, I think too, it's a great story. To me, it is a business where you have rising demand, you have rising supply of things that can be done, and you have an electoral process. Let's people vote themselves into healthcare.

Health care is percent of GDP, I think, must or will have to rise. That's my opinion.

LACQUA: John, pretty quickly. Are you concerned about China? We seem to be in the benign belief that China is fine. What if it were and what is that do to U.S. stocks?

MANLEY: That's a lot of problems. And we still want to get too close to the Yellow River. That happened before I was born. Nothing good comes with that. Again, we have some slowly here -- the North Korean/China situation is one of the unknowables out there. And it is a big disconcerting at this point in time. It's heating up.

My guess is, is if we do anything, it will be decisive and very quick but you'll never know about these things as it's just the risk that you just have to live with the time being.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much just for joining us. He is John Manley and he is a Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo Asset Management.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
