GURA: John, what's your sense of the degree to which this Fed Reserve, this Federal Open Market Committee is paying attention to the market? How big a concern is that for them?

MANLEY: I think they read the papers and, obviously, they listen to some very good radio broadcast from time to time. They have to be aware. I mean, you know, it's like asking your doctor did he read the thermometer after he test you.

We're pretty didn't care to what's going on. We're not perfect. We bounce around in awful lot. But we're pretty good in here.

And now, I think it's also important to remember, the fed and the capital markets and the economy are linked, because when the fed wants to push money at the economy, it goes through us first. So then let's think of it as a pipe carrying out, in or out of the economy. They sort of look at us, they get an obvious sign as money headed the right direction And, you know, they see a meltdown in stock market a little bit, they know that's can't be good for the rest of the real world.

The same thing is true for housing and a few others things. Look at what wealth is doing. If wealth is being created or at least maintained, they've got to feel reasonably comfortable.

GURA: And look at the soft data, you look the surveys, how businesses feel, their willingness to hire, their willingness to expand. And it seems like there is still a gap between the soft data and the hard data.

As you look at these earnings reports, what's the sense that you have of when the two are going to meet? Where we're going to see companies try to invest more in CAPEX?

MANLEY: I think you're starting to see -- I think what you have to realize too is that when -- it probably happen quickly because we're still on a fairly competitive landscape. And so far, it's been better for corporations who are competing against other corporations to buyback shares, to reinvest in their businesses by buying into their businesses. That doesn't have capacity obviously.

But at some point in time, it's not because the companies want to do it, it's because their consumers are demanding more of their products. If you and I are competing and I see you beginning to pick up share because you expand a little bit, watch out quickly, I would start my CAPEX of them.

LACQUA: John, are market merger is good for evaluations or bad?

MANLEY: Well, it depends on merger it has.

LACQUA: I know, in the industry, but -- because, you know, in general, just full of desperation.

MANLEY: I think that merge is to create synergy without being tremendously destructive to jobs, to create more efficient, more logical corporations are generally good. You don't want restraining the trade. I don't want restraining the trade. You do want efficiencies. You do want logical structures to a degree they foster that, I think it's fine. You just always keep your eyes open. There's nothing wrong with regulation. It's just got to be done, you know, a fair, even-handed way.

LACQUA: John, you know, we went into 2017, looking at Brexit, looking at President Trump. And there was this wave of anti-populism of -- or populism anti-globalization. Should that do anything to stock markets?

MANLEY: Well, it hasn't. I mean, there's an old saying, expect the worse and you'll never be disappointed. And the things to market has not been disappointed this year.

People talk about the lack of downside volatility. The only explanation for that is there have been non-negative surprises or any consequence. Well, so many negative things that come out of Washington or (inaudible) or even Berlin or Paris, how can one say there aren't negative surprises? Of course, there are negative.

Well, the thing is it's not a surprise. I think investors have a fairly low expectation, maybe a very low expectation of what comes out of Washington or Berlin or Britain. And I think in that respect, it's going to be pretty hard to disappoint us.]

GURA: Let me ask about financials in particular. A number of banks have reported already. How enthusiastic are you about financial stocks at this point? And how radically have they sort of trigged around from where we're a few years back?

MANLEY: Well, 40 years ago, I made choices from my life amongst them, so --

GURA: Yes.

MANLEY: -- we're very intimate with financial stocks and financial corporations and all the big -- it can be the best business and the worst business in the world. And believe me, I've seen both.

I think what you have to look for is reasonable regulation. There is no way that banks or financial institutions should be wide open. On the other hand, regulation go too far. You look for just the amount of regulation that seems to be moving in the right direction.

Interest rates also have corporations when they're facing very, very low rates, have a very difficult time placing fees on things that should have fees on them. If that's the case, their earnings power is being starved. Higher rates to a degree, it doesn't represent real fed tightening allows financial corporations to charge those fees, right adjustable fees that tends to improve their profitability. I think that part still in front of them.

GURA: Let me ask you how much personality matters. We spent some time this morning on television talking about Stuart Gulliver who is outgoing head of HSBC. You look at who's heading up these banks now. You can say few more years left and a lot of these guys who are running these banks. And how worried are you about transition? How much do you associate performances, the big bangs in particular with the men, largely men who are running those companies?

MANLEY: That's really good question. I don't know the straight answer I can give you. I think a character. When I invest my money over the long term, I know I can't possibly know what's going to happen in 5, 10 years. But I can look at the corporate culture, I guess that's where giving else. A good corporate culture should have depth, strong managers, truly strong managers, shouldn't be afraid of having people alongside them from replacing. That's the whole idea.

And I think that's a good way to buy stocks. You might want to find a good industry. But find a good industry that's being run by good men and women, who bring up good men and women internally. And I think you have -- it could be a fair of good investment.

LACQUA: And so, you have that in financials done or are you just talking about another industry?

MANLEY: We're talking industries in general and some financials --

LACQUA: Right.

MANLEY: I'm not assuming bad that I don't believe you.

LACQUA: OK. So which industries do you think are doing better in terms of succession but also, you know, having fewer legacy issues?

MANLEY: Well, the fundamentals were -- I think the fundamentals will come through. I think health care is a great sort of hard (ph) parts had collision between an Asian population like myself, improving health care, technology, and representative markers that can vote the money towards the people who need it.

I think technology, which we've been talking about, business to business technology, I think you're going to see wage pressures in the next few years. And the only way to cheapskates around corporations are going to let that go through is that they can prove productivity somehow, and that means spending on technology.

We mentioned financials, and for sure down in our value, I still think, well it was pretty good place to be. I'm focused on the big high quality large paying dividend stocks in the oil industry.

LACQUA: And those are mainly, which ones?

MANLEY: Well, I can't name them.

LACQUA: No, I know you can't. But is it -- on which end, is it refinery or is it actually downstream?

MANLEY: Well, the ones that are integrated, say a little bit of both.

LACQUA: All right.

GURA: We'll leave it there, John Manley. We'll come back with John Manley here in a just a moment. Maybe talk a bit more about Washington, its effects on policy, a little bit more on central banking as well. John Manley, Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo joining us here on Bloomberg 1130 studios on Bloomberg Surveillance.

(BREAK)

GURA: David Gura and Francine Lacqua, Tom Keene off today. This is Bloomberg Surveillance on Bloomberg Radio. Brought to you by Invesco for concise market and economic insights, delivered to your inbox weekly, count on Invesco Global Market Strategist, Kristina Hooper, invesco.com/hooper to learn more.

Continuing our conversation here with John Manley, Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo Funds. And, John, let me just ask you about what we're seeing play out in Washington, D.C. The result of this optimism after the election after the inauguration, safe to say, some of that is anticipated. Why are we not seeing more of a market move as a result of that?

MANLEY: Well, fundamentals are getting better. I mean that -- ex Washington, you're seeing earnings expectations arise after a long period of time where they really went nowhere. Also, the fed is being beneficial I guess is the right word. The fed is being very careful about what they do there. Shown very, very strong high levels of awareness about what they do. And the valuations aren't that bad.

I think the -- how shall I put this? The intricacies of Donald Trump presidency were probably discounted the first 12 hours as president-elect. And after that, we probably didn't have much expectation. We may say things but I don't think we really believed or counted on him. So hence, no negative surprises.

GURA: How about the fed's balance sheet? We've got more detail from the fed on how that's going to unfold, when it does begin to unfold the last meeting relatively soon. It was the watch phrase that came out of the statement following it. How that's that going to play out in your world? How that's going to play in the equities space in particular?

MANLEY: Well, it's a risk and therefore I think it proceed slowly. Jenny Donell (ph) was on recently saying, you know, we don't really know exactly how this is going to play because we've never done something like this before. What does a wise person, what does a wise man or woman do when they're in an unknown territory? They move slowly and carefully and they check every step they make. And I think that's what's going to happen. I think a lot of lessons from the real world are going to be applied in the financial world.

No guarantees right. Maybe these are undoable but I think a lot of things that were supposedly undoable have gotten done in the last few years. So, I think this -- it will work. I'm optimistic. I think the fed will be very, very careful in how they proceed.

LACQUA: What do you mean by lessons, John? So, you're talking about lessons from the real world being transferred in the financial world.

MANLEY: Well, I mean -- I'm just taking at -- act the way you would in real life. If you're on a dark path and you don't know where you are, you don't take big steps, you take small steps and check your footing every single step along the way. That's what Janet Yellen will do the financial code (ph) enough in my opinion.

LACQUA: Right. But the problem is that then financial stocks are always on notaire, right? They're going from record high to record high. What about then pausing and having a look right, left and center?

MANLEY: Sure. I mean I think that's possible. I've learned enough to -- since I can't really predict 5 percent or 10 percent pullbacks with any sort of accuracy, I just sort of assumed they're a part, they're a cost of earning equities for the long term. I think it's a worthwhile cost which I think equities and the delivers as pure return over a long period of time to very patient investors.

But you cannot expect to know every little wiggle and twist is going to be. So it could easily be a 5 percent correction because of something that goes slightly wrong, a 10 percent correction. But I think it will be done right at the end of the day. And when it's done right, there's a lot of room for these stocks to be meaningfully higher.

GURA: John Manley, we've talked about financials a few minutes ago. Let me ask about a couple of other sectors. I'll start with technology. When you look at tech with large, do you think that it's fairly valued right now?

MANLEY: If I understood half of it, I'd probably say it was fairly -- you know, the really big ones are really expensive ones --

GURA: Yes.

MANLEY: -- there's a lesson to those. I learned this back in the late '90s. The valuations may be frightening. The valuations maybe frightening but evaluations at the end of the day isn't what's it. The valuations will not tell you. They may win you.

Every time I've seen a highly valued, high growth country or company or industry blow up solely because valuation, it was like watching a man fall down and up escalator. You may fall but you get pulled harder, almost always buying opportunities. And I saw that to the late '90s.

And it's because the surprise is -- if stock goes down and the earnings expectations go up, you sort of have a correction double click in the stock. All right, it was ahead of itself is now 30 percent cheaper. People buy into it. You go tweet this a few times. People become less ordered by valuations.

So, watch valuations always they can trip you up but I don't think it's more than a trip. Focus, I would say, on the business to business -- the real spending in tech over the next several years is going to be by business to make their workers more productive so they can pay them more.

GURA: And thank you very much there would be escalated. Let me ask you lastly about health care. We're a point where the government -- where the administration is evaluating whether or not to continue with a subsidies on some levels of insurance. Obviously, had the big debate over health care. Your keen on health care overall, when you look at this as a sector?

MANLEY: Right. You know, falling down and not escalate naturally leads to health care, I would say. Yes, I think too, it's a great story. To me, it is a business where you have rising demand, you have rising supply of things that can be done, and you have an electoral process. Let's people vote themselves into healthcare.

Health care is percent of GDP, I think, must or will have to rise. That's my opinion.

LACQUA: John, pretty quickly. Are you concerned about China? We seem to be in the benign belief that China is fine. What if it were and what is that do to U.S. stocks?

MANLEY: That's a lot of problems. And we still want to get too close to the Yellow River. That happened before I was born. Nothing good comes with that. Again, we have some slowly here -- the North Korean/China situation is one of the unknowables out there. And it is a big disconcerting at this point in time. It's heating up.

My guess is, is if we do anything, it will be decisive and very quick but you'll never know about these things as it's just the risk that you just have to live with the time being.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much just for joining us. He is John Manley and he is a Chief Equities Strategist at Wells Fargo Asset Management.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We have the numbers full of analysis. Dow component, Goldman Sachs out in the last hour. The profit slips six percent. It did bait but the overall net income was down six percent but it still raises quarterly dividend from $0.85 to $1.25. And that is certainly helped power that stock higher.

Blue Chips, Johnson & Johnson, JP Morgan reporting earlier, also beating expectations with JP Morgan Chase's stock is down more than 1.5 percent in premarket trading. But it is worth noting that stock while underperforming JP Morgan stock leading up to the report underperforming the financial sector. It's still up about 17 percent year-to-date before these earnings report.

This follows another day of records on Wall Street. The Futures right now are putting to a higher open. Yesterday's close fresh new all-time highs for all your major market gauges. In Europe, your buying across the board in England, France, and Germany. The biggest gainer there the CAC 40 France up more than half of one percent.

And in Asia overnight, mixed markets there. The Nikkei and shanghai lower, Hong Kong and South Korea higher. China's premiere just saying that downward pressure on China's economy is increasing. This follows the report that the economy grew at 6.2 percent in the most recent quarter. That is the weakest pace in the least 27 years.

High-tech threat, billionaire Peter Thiel warning that Google is a threat to national security. Google has worked with China. This a company that refused to work with Defense Department because of employ -- push back on the artificial intelligence initiative, Project Maven. President Donald Trump just responding saying his administration will take a look at these allegations.

I've got a fantastic panel here. Let me go to Ashley Webster with these Wells Fargo numbers. Ashley, what do you say?

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK OVERSEAS MARKETS EDITOR: All right. Hey, Dagen, we have a beat on top and bottom. Let's take a look at the earnings per share coming in 1.30. The estimate was for 1.15 so a beat on earnings. Then on the revenue side, coming at $21.6 billion, the estimate was for $20.93 billion so we have a nice beat on the earnings, and on the revenue side.

Just looking at the net interest income at 12.1 billion. Net interest margin, so-called NIM, the difference between interest they pay out to depositors and the interest they get back on loans. That's at 2.82 percent, a little less than was expected. Overall 6.2 billion in quarterly net income so again, that works out at $1.30 on the earnings per share.

Let's be honest, this is a company Wells Fargo that still looking for a CEO. The latest person to step down, of course, was back in March when we had Mr. Sloan, Tim Sloan step down after being with the company 31 years. That's a big issue. Of course, they have big sale scandal back in 2016, trying to rebuild its reputation.

But apparently, finding someone else to take over at Wells Fargo has been difficult. We're waiting to see what they say in this note about the progress in that whether they promote someone from the inside or whether they will try and persuade someone on outside to come in and take over at Wells Fargo. So this is a company that still does not have a CEO after that scandal.

Dagen, back to you. It's interesting to see the premarket up about half a percent, up $0.23 for Wells Fargo. And again, they beat on earnings and revenue.

MCDOWELL: There was a name that was being floated, someone who worked at Bank of America Cathy Bessant, but again, we're still waiting. And again, if you take this job, you're in -- and this is figuratively speaking, you are in the crosshairs of Elizabeth Warren.

Again, she has been quite vocal. She got into a tiff with the head of the office of the comptroller of the currency over Tim -- over Tim Sloan in the oversight of the bank. So again, everything financial is political, and everything political is financial.

WEBSTER: You are absolutely right, Dagen. If you want the job, good luck.

MCDOWELL: Good luck and bring your suit of armor. Ashley Webster, thank you so much. Joining me now CFRA Director of Equity Research Ken Leon. Ken, so you've had some time to go over not Wells Fargo is just breaking but going over numbers that we've gotten out this morning,

If you look at the bank stocks particularly JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs, what do you make of the picture that these financials are painting so far?

KEN LEON, RESEARCH DIRECTOR, CFRA RESEARCH: We're seeing strength where you would expect it which is in the consumer banking, card businesses. Capital markets, there's a wall of worry. This really relates to uncertainty with trade tariffs. That filters into CEO confidence which affects underwriting. And M&A, big drops, across all banks.

That again is the question of getting those deals done where the removal of a large IPO in Asia related to Budweiser. So that creates an opportunity if we get some visibility of removal, things like China trade. You know, Wells Fargo, they're actually doing well. The wheels are not falling off the wagon. This bank not only probably had a good quarter today but they had great return of capital from the Fed.

Now, there's two areas, one is the CEO, the other is the lift. I think it's almost as big as the CEO of the concent to order. You go back two years ago, Federal Reserve, other agencies say, we're not going to let you grow your assets. That's a tough thing for banks and yet they're having pretty good results.

So I would say for this current management with an interim CEO, it's pretty good. And then we'll see it based on events ahead.

MCDOWELL: John, what do you make of all of this? And if we have a question --

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S CAPITAL MARKETS: Well, I think we're finding out I guess. As the trading front, banks are having difficulty. They're not getting enough volatility. You mention M&A, that's down sharply. What we noticed that Moody's is that with this drop in M&A volumes, we're seeing a deep drop by leveraged loan activity. That's dried up. So again banks don't necessarily hold on to these leveraged loans. For the most part they go out to CLOs and whatnot.

So I think on the market's front, the outlook remains murky depending upon the consumer. The consumer will come through for you as long as the unemployment rate drips lower. It's a different story however, once we finally reach that point where the recovery comes to an end and the unemployment rate begins to rise.

LEON: So trading today is different than the last 25 years. These banks particularly Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley wants stable recurring revenue. Trading is becoming less of an impact on their business and there's some areas tucked in there like client services which are generally more stable and doing better.

Interesting pie chart on Goldman Sachs release, 40 percent of their revenue comes from asset management and investing and lending. So those are areas they can control. You can't control the markets. And generally, that's why these stocks historically have had lower multiples.

MCDOWELL: I want to ask you a question because if you just read through Goldman Sachs -- and I want to -- I want to get to Goldman Sachs increasing its dividend which is a pretty big hike in its dividend, but there's uncertainty.

Again, you saw it in the trading activity among institutional clients, uncertainty over the trade fight, uncertainty over even the ratification of the trade deal with Mexico and Canada. Does that -- does that eventually translate into the consumer?

John says it's really based on the job market and when -- and when the expansion runs out but the consumers seem kind of immune impervious to this trade fight?

LEON: Well, the consumer so far has high confidence. That's terrific. I want to point out though that it's not Canada but its Europe. And the management, they are not going to be aggressive, but they have open field running to take market share in Europe. We have Deutsche Bank, we have other banks.

Again, back to my point of getting back to more stable businesses away from trading, away from high-risk investment banking, and certain products. These are good opportunities for Goldman, JP Morgan, later this week Morgan Stanley.

LONSKI: I have a question about demographic change. I can't help but notice, we've gone to a situation where nearly -- the number of people 65 and older in the U.S. growing by nearly two million people this year, big difference from the past, and this means a lot of 401k plans need to be managed. Is this helping banks?

LEON: It does help banks. And we're talking wealth management, we're talking about even with a lower rate environment, lower net interest income, maybe. But to your point, if you have increased investment accounts, higher assets of their management, all of a sudden we're saying that interest income this week flat to slightly up, absolutely.

MCDOWELL: You've seen moves. All of these banks know the importance of the consumer. Goldman Sachs has shifted to consumer banking money management in recent years, and I think and correct me if I'm wrong, Ken, JPMorgan has tried to go after the discount brokers by now offering this commission-free arrangement for its clients. These are all moves again to create more consistent revenue stream.

LEON: It's a question of whether you're the incumbent or you're the new disruptors. So for JPMorgan, Bank of America, or Wells Fargo, they're being thoughtful in terms of their branches or financial centers. They still pull in business.

Goldman Sachs is a disrupter. They are essentially using markets and leveraging that into a bigger picture of over $1 trillion asset management business for those tiers, high net worth, mass market, and retail. So it's very interesting to see what's playing out early but it's going to be over the next few years.

MCDOWELL: This is a big dividend increase though.

LEON: It is and I don't want to lose sight to the Federal Reserve approving the stress test capital returns. Goldman a year ago, there was a conditional approval, no dividend increase. This year they got it and it's big. And that's going to give confidence possibly to a value investor looking for yields.

MCDOWELL: It helps when the government gets out of the way, doesn't it?

LONSKI: You know, I want to point -- and one final point is that banks are much stronger financially. The capitalization now is so much deeper than it was back in 2006, 2007. I think that's a favorable development over time.

MCDOWELL: And that's a relief, John.

LEON: It's a relief and you're going from really 2015 to today to -- these are almost becoming normalized yield plays. Pay-out ratios are still high but they have way too much capital, and you sometimes hear analysts saying, well, is your pay-out ratio 90, you're 100 percent too high. They have too much capital obviously, we are seeing many of these banks get their earnings per share with eight to ten percent reduction of outstanding shares.

MCDOWELL: So I -- this is tease for coming up but I have a theory about the bank bailout is still playing out in politics today. It gave rise to the Tea Party and it's really the root of what Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren are talking about, where is my bailout. That's what the root of it. Ken, it was great to see you.

LEON: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much for seeing the world, and being with us all morning long on earnings. urn:contentItem:60BD-8P81-DYTY-C4NX-00000-00Well, thank God that'sall over…;Lockdown is behind us - for now. But what did we learn? We asked our writers to reveal the fads and fixes that made life bearable, from what we ate and wore to how we socialised and exercised2020-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisSUNDAY TRAVEL;FEATURESPg. 1,2,3Well, thank God that'sall over…Lockdown is behind us - for now. But what did we learn? We asked our writers to reveal the fads and fixes that made life bearable, from what we ate and wore to how we socialised and exercised

there weren't enough hours in the day.

What I'd love HARRY DE QUETTEVILLE ON THE T ECH THAT CONNECTED US So how many video conferencing apps do you have installed now, eh? Who imagined there could be so many, jostling for screen space and disk space, desperately claiming to be Numero Uno at keeping you face to face with your office/your chums/your children's virtual birthday party invitees…? Skype we knew. And FaceTime too. But then came Zoom. Don't forget Hangouts. Or Slack. Or Teams. Did you get round to GoToMeeting? I'M Will Houseparty, that blazing star of lockdown's early days, downloaded 17 million times in March, continue to soar across the virtual firmament now that measures are easing? I'm not sure.

Video With down or tech in the staying.

. What never again schooling. tech possible.

But in general all those tools that allowed us effortlessly to toil and play remotely are staying, as the long-term impacts of the pandemic - smaller offices, genuine flexitime, distance learning and working - make themselves felt.

The limiting factor will not be desire but internet speeds. How many happy hipsters relocating from Hackney to Hampshire will find that the new virtual tools of their trade require more than piddling rural bandwidth? As for that mobile signal… Social media, we know already, will go unreformed. How quickly the solidarity of those early days broke down into the usual political bickering and point-scoring.

On Instagram, there were perhaps marginally fewer humblebrag pictures - "just relaxing in the amazing Highland landscape" - as urbanites hunkered down and realised that rubbing their lockdown escape in other people's faces was not the done thing, indeed was potentially illegal. "We're all in this together" is the very antithesis of the bitter spirit that fuels some social media envy-engines. But sadly, gentler ways have already faded online.

For some, of course, virtual meetings have actually been an improvement. GPs have whizzed through the appointments. The bias towards remote consultations will stay - so much cheaper, more efficient, allowing more time for those that really need the in-person treatment.

My parents-in-law rhapsodise about the app they use to play Bridge remotely, no driving to and fro, no tedious shuffling cards or tallying points. Plenty of chance to chat over an open phone line.

The pandemic has even breached that previously impervious legislative barrier: the Highway Act 1835, in combination with the Road Traffic Act 1988, which made electric scooters illegal wherever you took them: road, cycle lane or pavement.

This very week, a 12-month trial has begun, sanctioned by the Government, to see how electric scooters fit into the urban transport mix. Surely they are here to stay, especially as suspicion of enclosed and often crowded public transport endures.

Indeed, tech generally has been the big winner this pandemic, as you will know if you follow the share prices of Silicon Valley's finest. Not only have the world's biggest companies stepped in to ensure personal connectivity, they have been swiftly ushered into state-like business - just look at the NHS partnering with big tech, or the deployment by nations of the Apple/Google tracing app.

There is little that now seems beyond the reach of the biggest companies. So the most significant question post-lockdown will be this: will there be a backlash against their pervasiveness and power? During lockdown, if anything, latitude was granted. The UK Information Commissioner's Office announced that firms would have longer than usual to fix data breaches. Corona concerns saw Amazon's investment in Deliveroo approved by the Competition and Markets Authority, which also shied away from a full investigation of the online advertising industry so dominated by Facebook and Google.

But now lockdown is easing, regulation may climb back up the political agenda. Too Big to Fail became a critical issue in the financial crisis. Too big to catch, to compete with, to scrutinise properly, to do without, may soon be the issue for big tech. If that is so, our corona love affair with technology may be heading for a big break-up.

I'M PERSISTING WITH… Video conferencing. With my parents down the road, or tech wizards in the US, it's staying.. What I hope never to do again is… Home schooling. The tech made it possible. But . What I'd love to keep doing but probably shouldn't… Working from home. I love it. But I suspect I'll drift back to the office when it opens again.

MICHAEL HOGAN ON THE T V MOMENTS THAT TRANSFIXED US You'll get square eyes," is what parents used to say to children who watched too much telly. If the old wives' tale is true, we'll all have emerged from lockdown square-eyed, stragglyhaired, slightly overweight and unaccustomed to social interaction. An accurate description of most TV critics at the best of times, as it goes.

Stats say that Britons have watched 51 per cent more TV than usual over these past four months - from government briefings to binge-worthy box sets, from sport in eerily empty stadiums to repeated reality www.shows.No wonder there was a stampede to the pub at the earliest opportunity.

Lockdown's first water cooler hit - or with everybody working from home, "kitchen tap hit" might be more accurate - was Netflix true crime freak show Tiger King. This stranger-than-fiction tale of big cats, bad fashion and murder plots doesn't look like going away any time soon. A dramatised version is in the works, with Nicolas Cage playing redneck Joe Exotic. Purrfect casting.

The BBC's addictive adaptation of Sally Rooney's Normal People had us obsessing over the mumblings and fumbling of two lovestruck Irish teens. Daisy Edgar-Jones excelled as privileged-butdamaged Marianne but Paul Mescal, aka workingclass romantic Connell, became the breakout star. His silver chain necklace and short shorts trended on Twitter. With talk of him being the next James Bond, Mescal-mania looks here to stay.

Spring TV's ratings sensations were a pair of fact-based dramas. ITV's Quiz (bravely for 2020, a drama about coughing) and BBC One's The Salisbury Poisonings were both cleverly stripped across the schedules over three consecutive nights, became event TV, and duly pulled in 10 million viewers. A dramatisation called The Leicester Lockdown might be in the pipeline already.

With the shutters coming down on TV production, remote filming came into its own. We've had Zoom King, dramas (Staged, Isolation Stories, Talking Heads), Zoom chat shows (The Graham Norton Show, Loose Women, Later… with Jools Holland) and Zoom panel games (Have I Got News For You). Handy for nosing at famous people's houses but I suspect we'll be so sick of video-calls that we'll never want to see such stilted, glitching awkwardness again. Grayson Perry's Art Club was the only offering that might have legs after lockdown is lifted.

Perhaps pandemic TV's biggest surprise has been the reinvention of professional motormouth Piers Morgan. He's gone from shouty irritant on Good Morning Britain to Covid-19's inquisitor-in-chief. Even long-suffering co-host Susanna Reid has stopped rolling her eyes as much.

Fundraising funnyman Matt Lucas became a lockdown hero (thank you, baked potato) and as the new host of Bake Off, could soon become even more beloved. However, the glitterball stopped spinning for Sophie Ellis-Bextor's Friday night "kitchen discos" - in which she'd glam up and belt out floor-fillers while dodging her five dancing children - around the same time we stopped clapping for carers.

not People, Tiger DIY satire became the hot TikTok trend, thanks to Michael Spicer's "room next door" skits and the lipsync Trump spoofs by US comedian Sarah Cooper. She soon spawned a British equivalent in voice artist Meggie Foster. Skewering politicians with their own words somehow suited the absurdity of lockdown life, but let's hope these new talents stick around.

Another thing we certainly hope continues is the gatecrashing of live interviews by children. With home-working parents and homeschooled kids, it's become more frequent, and always makes us feel much better about our own chaotic lockdown lives.

In the immortal words of Sky News foreign affairs editor Deborah Haynes's son: "Mummy, can I have two biscuits?" With those bargaining skills, the boy will go far.

WE'LL KEEP ON WITH… Family films and board games every weekend.. What I hope never to do again is… Frantically gesticulate at someone to unmute themselves on Zoom.

. What I would love to keep doing but probably shouldn't… Crossing the street to avoid annoying people under the guise of "social distancing".

SHANE WATSON ON THE WAY W E WORE (AND SHOPPED) The thing about lockdown was it didn't matter what you wore. Some people had Zoom meetings and needed to make an effort on top, the rest of us had permission to go full Sunday slob and wear the same loose grey clothes, day after day. So what did we do, as soon as we were free to dress like bums? We started shopping.

First there was the exercise wear phase. Within days it became clear that lockdown was creating a new competitive environment: instead of being the busiest, youngestlooking, mother of minimum four, the trick was to be the fittest and the best cook, but mainly the fittest. And for that challenge we realised we required brand new exercise kit. (Also by now we had seen a young woman going through her routine in the park wearing a black Nike racing back T and three-quarter leggings and decided that while we couldn't wear the shorts her friend was wearing, we could certainly give that look a whirl). I'm still wearing my Nike gear, because it makes me feel like the sort of Californian yuppie who would never dream of getting stuck into the pinot grigio at three minutes past six, and might, in fact, go for a run instead. Before the lockdown I hooted at the idea of smart exercise wear; now I'm a believer in its motivational powers.

Then in early April, phase two kicked in: the "Mustn't Turn into A Bloke" phase. Remember in 30 Rock when Jack Donaghy tells Lemon to get out of her sporty clothes and go and buy some "from a womenswear store"? Well, that's roughly what we told ourselves, partly because we were starting to feel like leathery old cat burglars and partly because it was hot, the blossom was out, and we felt the need of a flippy dress. It must be said that the dresses we ordered in P2 were a lot prettier than our usual and there was, in hindsight, an element of escapism going on. Fairly sure (since I haven't worn them) that the purchase of the yellow one with puffed sleeves, and the pink flowery one, was brought on by the springtime-in-Rome weather. The drop earrings, same thing.

Phase three was "Let's Make This a 1970s Summer". Was it all the rainbows in the windows? Was it the summer of '76 weather, the shaggy untended hair and working in the garden with a cup of tea and the radio on (which did feel a lot like O-level revision week)? Whatever, there was something 1970s in the air, and in May our thoughts turned to denim skirts (ordered! Worn!). Clogs (ordered! Worn!) A maxi skirt in Indian cotton blockprint (ordered! Not worn). And dungarees (ordered. Sent back on account of the fit).

doing lockdown (but could)…

old dress in Meanwhile thousands of women are lockdown dungaree converts and it's not just because they're comfy.

They make you feel the way we want to feel now - resourceful, practical, not precious, and free - like Meryl Streep in Mamma Mia. Will I be wearing the 1970s stuffout in the new world? Oh yes.

This is going to be a slow, Scrabble and sou'westers, 1970s kind of summer.

Phase four - the one we're in - is the Hope Chest phase. It started at the beginning of June, about the time we'd accepted that we were going nowhere on holiday, and went shopping anyway - for swimming costumes, sunglasses, the sort of top you can only wear in a place with ceiling fans and mosquito nets.

They turned up one after the other in hot pink tissue paper looking bright and cheering and that was half the point. The swimsuit (Boden Santorini, works like Spanx) will come in useful, the rest we can stuffunder a hoodie and a waterproof poncho and we're good to go.

I'LL STILL BE WEARING…Clogs. What I hope never to do again is… Wear high heels. The thing I won't be able to carry on doing now lockdown has ended (but wish I could)… Wear an old cotton dress that's ripped in six places.

JOEL SNAPE ON THE F ITNESS TRENDS THAT F LOORED US Dedicated gymjunkies have known for years what the rest of the country has come to realise over the last few months: that finding time to train is more about mental health than shedding pounds or adding them to the bar. In lockdown, that's become even more important - for thousands of people, carving out even 20 minutes a day to have a brisk run, a leisurely stroll or a few horrible rounds of burpees, has become a way to set everything else aside and focus on your own well-being, and I hope that's a trend that will continue as commutes creep back and hangovers kick in.

I'LL "Crazy that my hangs as I do dogs flow. What never again the to make get at Leading the charge for feelgood fitness, of course, was Joe Wicks, a man so enthusiastic about the benefits of exercise that he somehow made doing lunges in a Scooby-Doo suit - at 9am every day, for months - look a bit like fun. Wicks, and the rest of YouTube's most personable trainers, are likely to be some of the biggest beneficiaries of lockdown - they've seen their followings grow, and some people are unlikely to go back to the gym for months, if at all. Bespoke options are becoming more globalised, as Zoom yoga classes allow anyone to jump in and gyms live-stream classes for anyone who wants them.

Impersonal offline trainers - the ones who don't do much more than repcount and cheerlead - are likely to suffer, as their clients realise they can find cheaper, more cheerful alternatives online. Proper personal trainers, who provide the sort of feedback on form and targeted training that you can't get from generic plans, will, hopefully, thrive.

What will the other long-lasting effects be? With luck, some of the people who bought up the entire European stock of kettlebells and pull-up bars will actually use them. Moving outdoors, the reputation of joggers might never recover: they've often been stereotyped as pavement-hogs, and the way most of them ignored social distancing, panting and droplet-spraying their way past slower park users, hasn't helped. Top tip, runners: you can run sideways a bit without ruining your gait or your gains. It might even help your ankle stability! If Couch to 5K has helped you rediscover the joy of bounding around the park, great. Just spare a thought for the pensioners and pram-pushers who do not care about your PB.

Still on selfishness, what remains to be seen is how gyms are going to fare in a post-lockdown world: it's likely only places in touch with their clientele will survive. Pre-Covid, a solid 20 per cent of gymgoers wouldn't even deign to put their dumbbells back, so expecting them to wipe down treadmills, benches and bars, unsupervised, seems like a forlorn hope.

Boutique gyms may do better: many already have protocols for cleaning kit between classes, and as hygiene remains top-ofmind that'll be key. Whether group fitness classes will resurge is tricky to predict - there's something about competing in a group that's tough to match at home, but since it's currently impossible to watch people shake hands in a period drama without a twinge of horror, holding someone's legs while they do crunches feels a long way off.

Still, if there's one positive fitness effect, let it be an end to the creeping ubiquity of post-class high-fives, chest-bumps and bro-hugs, in favour of the fist-bump, bow, or Vulcan salute.

I'LL KEEP ON PLAYING… "Crazy Horse", that game where my toddler hangs on to me as I do pressups, downward dogs and animal flow moves.. What I hope never to do again is… Go to the shops at 6am to make sure I get at least some fresh veg for the week.. What I would love to keep doing but probably shouldn't… Leave my pull-up rig up in the background of Zoom calls. The gym rings just prompt too many questions.

regular joe Wicks, the nation's favourite trainer, is loved. Joggers, above, are often not DEBORA ROBERTSON ON OUR FASCINATING FOOD FADS As we emerge into the sunlight, many of us having been confined to our four walls these past months, some of us are left pondering - as we ease our way back into proper clothes - how we allowed the hour-long health walk to become downgraded so quickly to the waddle to the fridge. Daily meditation became standing in its cold, cruel light, wondering what to eat next. Goodbye kimchi my old friend, I hope to eat with you again.

I'M CARRY Certainly, food - the getting of it, the cooking of it, the eating of it - has sustained us in more ways than one during this crisis.

Shopping order ingredients. really finding producers middle this and good to you are to support British companies, many of are having hard. What At the beginning, at the height of the supermarket slot panic, we became adept at finding new sources to replace our usual supermarket deliveries, from one-stopalternative-shop places such as Farmdrop or Farm Direct, to specialists selling one perfect thing, from mutton, to lobsters, goat, or asparagus.

Where I live in London, our local shops stepped up. My neighbourhood bakery, The Spence, provided the highlight of my Wednesday mornings, when I would wake to find a brown paper bag of bread, croissants, sausage rolls, various flours and fresh yeast on my doorstep. My butcher, Meat N16, turned its hand to local drop-offs. A bloke on a bike started delivering eggs by the dozen, usually within the hour. This return to the way our grandmothers shopped, with their favoured suppliers making regular weekday deliveries, for many of us reignited our loyalty to those local traders who were there when we needed them.

We also developed an excellent strand of greedy altruism. As restaurants closed, suppliers began to struggle to find outlets for their produce. Pioneering cheesemonger Neal's Yard Dairy and others created mail order boxes of cheeses to help keep suppliers going. Fighting the good fight, one slab of Kirkham's Lancashire at a time.

Having food delivered turned every day into a mini-Christmas, especially if, like me, you ordered things then instantly forgot you had. Lo, a beautiful box of Isle of Wight tomatoes in all shapes and sizes and every shade from golden through scarlet to almost black; a box of garlicky salamis; half a case of wine - move over gold, frankincense and myrrh, there are new gifts in town.

And then of course there was all the cooking. In shapeless days, meals formed the only highlight. Every night was Friday night. Simple was replaced by elaborate. If you ever fancied trying your hand at making your own biang biang noodles or chocolate babka, or perfecting your roast chicken, what better time than the endless now? For those who missed restaurants too much, many turned their hands to posh make-at-home ready meals that you could enjoy over your are-we-having-fun-yet Zoom dinner dates. And of course, we all became enormously wholesome. Social media posts about our sourdough, banana bread, kombucha and kefir replaced our actual social lives.

Then, just when the air was feeling a little rarefied up there in gourmetlockdown land, we reignited our love for that snack of snacks: crisps. What else could power us so well through those endless Netflix marathons (apart perhaps from buckets of gourmet popcorn)? Of course we need to talk about drink. At the beginning, when time meant nothing, the cocktail hour frequently nudged its way into tea time.

Christmas every day Food deliveries became a source of great excitement Some of us may have thought we were creating our very own Roaring Twenties with our frostyglassed gimlets, Martinis, greyhounds, and aviators. The rest of us were making hasty assemblies from the back of the drinks cabinet, suddenly finding a use for that 12-year-old bottle of blue curaçao that came with the house. The latter-day lockdown cocktail of choice though has become a mocktail, as smart non-alcoholic drinks like those from Seedlip, Dash and Punchy have gained ground. We've also bought more and better wine, as we've shopped just to please ourselves, rather than guests who don't necessarily know the difference between Vimto and Viognier.

What, if anything, will we take with us into our new "old" lives? With any luck, that feeling of how food has the power to anchor us as it nurtures us, and how if you do it right, every day can be made to feel like Christmas.

I'M GOING TO CARRY ON… Shopping mail order for special ingredients. I've really enjoyed finding new producers in the middle of all of this and it feels good to know you are helping to support British companies, many of which are having a hard time.. What I hope never to do again is… Set my alarm for 5am to see if I can bag an Ocado slot.. What I would love to keep doing but probably shouldn't as it feels lazy is… To have bread, meat and eggs delivered from my local shops - I could do with the walk.

urn:contentItem:60BF-K561-JCJY-G333-00000-00Well, thank God that's over: a lookback at lockdown's lifestyle trends;What we ate, wore and watched, and how we socialised and exercised during lockdown - and what it all meant2020-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisFAMILYVersion:1Well, thank God that's over: a lookback at lockdown's lifestyle trendsWhat we ate, wore and watched, and how we socialised and exercised during lockdown - and what it all meantBy Debora Robertson and Michael Hogan and Harry de Quetteville and Shane Watson and Joel Snape

What we ate, wore and watched, and how we socialised and exercised during lockdown - and what it all meant

Lockdown is over - for most of us, for now. How was it for you? And what did it all mean? Was it really only three months ago that we were binge-watching Tiger King? Did we really buy so much mail-order cheese? Did we need to buy so many clothes, and will we ever stop hating joggers, or Zoom meetings?

We asked Telegraph writers to reveal the fads and fixes that got them through the strangest few months that - we hope - we will ever have to experience.

Debora Robertson  on our fascinating food fads

As we emerge into the sunlight, many of us having been confined to our four walls these past months, some of us are left pondering - as we ease our way back into proper clothes - how we allowed the hour-long health walk to become downgraded so quickly to the waddle to the fridge. Daily meditation became standing in its cold, cruel light, wondering what to eat next. Goodbye kimchi my old friend, I hope to eat with you again.

Certainly, food - the getting of it, the cooking of it, the eating of it - has sustained us in more ways than one during this crisis.

At the beginning, at the height of the supermarket slot panic, we became adept at finding new sources to replace our usual supermarket deliveries, from one-stop-alternative-shop places such as Farmdrop or Farm Direct, to specialists selling one perfect thing, from mutton, to lobsters, goat, or asparagus.

Where I live in London, our local shops stepped up. My neighbourhood bakery, The Spence, provided the highlight of my Wednesday mornings, when I would wake to find a brown paper bag of bread, croissants, sausage rolls, various flours and fresh yeast on my doorstep. My butcher, Meat N16, turned its hand to local drop-offs. A bloke on a bike started delivering eggs by the dozen, usually within the hour. This return to the way our grandmothers shopped, with their favoured suppliers making regular weekday deliveries, for many of us reignited our loyalty to those local traders who were there when we needed them.

We also developed an excellent strand of greedy altruism. As restaurants closed, suppliers began to struggle to find outlets for their produce. Pioneering cheesemonger Neal's Yard Dairy and others created mail order boxes of cheeses to help keep suppliers going. Fighting the good fight, one slab of Kirkham's Lancashire at a time.

Having food delivered turned every day into a mini-Christmas, especially if, like me, you ordered things then instantly forgot you had. Lo, a beautiful box of Isle of Wight tomatoes in all shapes and sizes and every shade from golden through scarlet to almost black; a box of garlicky salamis; half a case of wine - move over gold, frankincense and myrrh, there are new gifts in town.

And then of course there was all the cooking. In shapeless days, meals formed the only highlight. Every night was Friday night. Simple was replaced by elaborate. If you ever fancied trying your hand at making your own biang biang noodles or chocolate babka, or perfecting your roast chicken, what better time than the endless now?

For those who missed restaurants too much, many turned their hands to posh make-at-home ready meals that you could enjoy over your are-we-having-fun-yet Zoom dinner dates. And of course, we all became enormously wholesome. Social media posts about our sourdough, banana bread, kombucha and kefir replaced our actual social lives.

Then, just when the air was feeling a little rarefied up there in gourmet-lockdown land, we reignited our love for that snack of snacks: crisps. What else could power us so well through those endless Netflix marathons (apart perhaps from buckets of gourmet popcorn)?

Of course we need to talk about drink. At the beginning, when time meant nothing, the cocktail hour frequently nudged its way into tea time. Some of us may have thought we were creating our very own Roaring Twenties with our frosty-glassed gimlets, Martinis, greyhounds, and aviators. The rest of us were making hasty assemblies from the back of the drinks cabinet, suddenly finding a use for that 12-year-old bottle of blue curaçao that came with the house. The latter-day lockdown cocktail of choice though has become a mocktail, as smart non-alcoholic drinks like those from Seedlip, Dash and Punchy have gained ground. We've also bought more and better wine, as we've shopped just to please ourselves, rather than guests who don't necessarily know the difference between Vimto and Viognier.

What, if anything, will we take with us into our new "old" lives? With any luck, that feeling of how food has the power to anchor us as it nurtures us, and how if you do it right, every day can be made to feel like  Christmas.

I'm going to  carry on...

Shopping mail order for special ingredients. I've really enjoyed finding new producers in the middle of all of this and it feels good to know you are helping to support British companies, many of which are having a hard time.

What I hope never to do again is... Set my alarm for 5am to see if I can bag an Ocado slot.

What I would love to keep doing but probably shouldn't as it feels lazy is... To have bread, meat and eggs delivered from my local shops - I could do with the walk.

 Michael Hogan  on the TV moments that transfixed us You'll get square eyes," is what parents used to say to children who watched too much telly. If the old wives' tale is true, we'll all emerge from lockdown square-eyed, straggly-haired, slightly overweight and unaccustomed to social interaction. An accurate description of most TV critics at the best of times, as it goes.Stats say that Britons have watched 51 per cent more TV than usual over these past four months - from government briefings to binge-worthy box sets, from sport in eerily empty stadiums to repeated reality shows. No wonder there was a stampede to the pub at the earliest opportunity.Lockdown's first water cooler hit - or with everybody working from home, "kitchen tap hit" might be more accurate - was Netflix true crime freak show Tiger King. This stranger-than-fiction tale of big cats, bad fashion and murder plots doesn't look like going away any time soon. A dramatised version is in the works, with Nicolas Cage playing redneck Joe Exotic. Purrfect casting.The BBC's addictive adaptation of Sally Rooney's Normal People had us obsessing over the mumblings and fumbling of two lovestruck Irish teens. Daisy Edgar-Jones excelled as privileged-but-damaged Marianne but Paul Mescal, aka working-class romantic Connell, became the breakout star. His silver chain necklace and short shorts trended on Twitter. With talk of him being the next James Bond, Mescal-mania looks here to stay.Spring TV's ratings sensations were a pair of fact-based dramas. ITV's Quiz (bravely for 2020, a drama about coughing) and BBC One's The Salisbury Poisonings were both cleverly stripped across the schedules over three consecutive nights, became event TV, and duly pulled in 10 million viewers. A dramatisation called The Leicester Lockdown might be in the pipeline already.With the shutters coming down on TV production, remote filming came into its own. We've had Zoom dramas (Staged, Isolation Stories, Talking Heads), Zoom chat shows (The Graham Norton Show, Loose Women, Later... with Jools Holland) and Zoom panel games (Have I Got News For You). Handy for nosing at famous people's houses but I suspect we'll be so sick of video-calls that we'll never want to see such stilted, glitching awkwardness again. Grayson Perry's Art Club was the only offering that might have legs after lockdown is lifted.Perhaps pandemic TV's biggest surprise has been the reinvention of professional motormouth Piers Morgan. He's gone from shouty irritant on Good Morning Britain to Covid-19's inquisitor-in-chief. Even long-suffering co-host Susanna Reid has stopped rolling her eyes as much.Fundraising funnyman Matt Lucas became a lockdown hero (thank you, baked potato) and as the new host of Bake Off, could soon become even more beloved. However, the glitterball stopped spinning for Sophie Ellis-Bextor's Friday night "kitchen discos" - in which she'd glam up and belt out floor-fillers while dodging her five dancing children - around the same time we stopped clapping for carers.DIY satire became the hot TikTok trend, thanks to Michael Spicer's "room next door" skits and the lipsync Trump spoofs by US comedian Sarah Cooper. She soon spawned a British equivalent in voice artist Meggie Foster. Skewering politicians with their own words somehow suited the absurdity of lockdown life, but let's hope these new talents stick around.Another thing we certainly hope continues is the gatecrashing of live interviews by children. With home-working parents and homeschooled kids, it's become more frequent, and always makes us feel much better about our own chaotic lockdown lives. In the immortal words of Sky News foreign affairs editor Deborah Haynes's son: "Mummy, can I have two biscuits?" With those bargaining skills, the boy will go far.We'll keep on with...

Family films and board games every weekend.

What I hope never to do again is... Frantically gesticulate at someone to unmute themselves on Zoom.

What I would love to keep doing but probably shouldn't... Crossing the street to avoid annoying people under the guise of "social distancing".

Shane Watson  on our fashion passionsThe thing about lockdown was it didn't matter what you wore. Some people had Zoom meetings and needed to make an effort on top, the rest of us had permission to go full Sunday slob and wear the same loose grey clothes, day after day. So what did we do, as soon as we were free to dress like bums? We started shopping.First there was the exercise wear phase. Within days it became clear that lockdown was creating a new competitive environment: instead of being the busiest, youngest-looking, mother of minimum four, the trick was to be the fittest and the best cook, but mainly the fittest. And for that challenge we realised we required brand new exercise kit. (Also by now we had seen a young woman going through her routine in the park wearing a black Nike racing back T and three-quarter leggings and decided that while we couldn't wear the shorts her friend was wearing, we could certainly give that look a whirl). I'm still wearing my Nike gear, because it makes me feel like the sort of Californian yuppie who would never dream of getting stuck into the pinot grigio at three minutes past six, and might, in fact, go for a run instead. Before the lockdown I hooted at the idea of smart exercise wear; now I'm a believer in its motivational powers.Then in early April, phase two kicked in: the "Mustn't Turn into A Bloke" phase. Remember in 30 Rock when Jack Donaghy tells Lemon to get out of her sporty clothes and go and buy some "from a womenswear store"? Well, that's roughly what we told ourselves, partly because we were starting to feel like leathery old cat burglars and partly because it was hot, the blossom was out, and we felt the need of a flippy dress.It must be said that the dresses we ordered in P2 were a lot prettier than our usual and there was, in hindsight, an element of escapism going on. Fairly sure (since I haven't worn them) that the purchase of the yellow one with puffed sleeves, and the pink flowery one, was brought on by the springtime-in-Rome weather. The drop earrings, same thing.Phase three was "Let's Make This a 1970s Summer". Was it all the rainbows in the windows? Was it the summer of '76 weather, the shaggy untended hair and working in the garden with a cup of tea and the radio on (which did feel a lot like O level revision week)? Whatever, there was something 1970s in the air, and in May our thoughts turned to denim skirts (ordered. Worn!). Clogs (ordered! Worn!) A maxi skirt in Indian cotton blockprint (ordered! Not worn). And dungarees (ordered. Sent back on account of the fit).Meanwhile thousands of women are lockdown dungaree converts and it's not just because they're comfy. They make you feel the way we want to feel now - resourceful, practical, not precious, and free - like Meryl Streep in Mamma Mia. Will I be wearing the 1970s stuff out in the new world? Oh yes. This is going to be a slow, Scrabble and sou'westers, 1970s kind of summer.Phase four - the one we're in - is the Hope Chest phase. It started at the beginning of June, about the time we'd accepted that we were going nowhere on holiday, and went shopping anyway - for swimming costumes, sunglasses, the sort of top you can only wear in a place with ceiling fans and mosquito nets.They turned up one after the other in hot pink tissue paper looking bright and cheering and that was half the point. The swimsuit (Boden Santorini, works like Spanx) will come in useful, the rest we can stuff under a hoodie and a waterproof poncho and we're good to go.I'll still be wearing...

Clogs

What I hope never to do again is... Wear high heels

The thing I won't be able to   carry on doing now lockdown has ended (but wish I could)... Wear an old cotton dress that's ripped in six places.

Joel Snape  on our healthy habitsDedicated gym-junkies have known for years what the rest of the country has come to realise over the last few months: that finding time to train is more about mental health than shedding pounds or adding them to the bar. In lockdown, that's become even more important - for thousands of people, carving out even 20 minutes a day to have a brisk run, a leisurely stroll or a few horrible rounds of burpees, has become a way to set everything else aside and focus on your own well-being, and I hope that's a trend that will continue as commutes creep back and hangovers kick in.Leading the charge for feelgood fitness, of course, was Joe Wicks, a man so enthusiastic about the benefits of exercise that he somehow made doing lunges in a Scooby-Doo suit - at 9am every day, for months - look a bit like fun. Wicks, and the rest of YouTube's most personable trainers, are likely to be some of the biggest beneficiaries of lockdown - they've seen their followings grow, and some people are unlikely to go back to the gym for months, if at all. Bespoke options are becoming more globalised, as Zoom yoga classes allow anyone to jump in and gyms live-stream classes for anyone who wants them.Impersonal offline trainers - the ones who don't do much more than rep-count and cheerlead - are likely to suffer, as their clients realise they can find cheaper, more cheerful alternatives online. Proper personal trainers, who provide the sort of feedback on form and targeted training that you can't get from generic plans, will, hopefully, thrive.What will the other long-lasting effects be?  With luck, some of the people who bought up the entire European stock of kettlebells and pull-up bars will actually use them. Moving outdoors, the reputation of joggers might never recover: they've often been stereotyped as pavement-hogs, and the way most of them ignored social distancing, panting and droplet-spraying their way past slower park users, hasn't helped. Top tip, runners: you can run sideways a bit without ruining your gait or your gains. It might even help your ankle stability!If Couch to 5K has helped you rediscover the joy of bounding around the park, great. Just spare a thought for the pensioners and pram-pushers who do not care about your PB.Still on selfishness, what remains to be seen is how gyms are going to fare in a post-lockdown world: it's likely only places in touch with their clientele will survive. Pre-Covid, a solid 20 per cent of gymgoers wouldn't even deign to put their dumbbells back, so expecting them to wipe down treadmills, benches and bars, unsupervised, seems like a forlorn hope.Boutique gyms may do better: many already have protocols for cleaning kit between classes, and as hygiene remains top-of-mind that'll be key. Whether group fitness classes will resurge is tricky to predict - there's something about competing in a group that's tough to match at home, but since it's currently impossible to watch people shake hands in a period drama without a twinge of horror, holding someone's legs while they do crunches feels a long way off.Still, if there's one positive fitness effect, let it be an end to the creeping ubiquity of post-class high-fives, chest-bumps and bro-hugs, in favour of the fist-bump, bow, or Vulcan salute.I'll keep on playing...

"Crazy Horse", that game where my toddler hangs on to me as I do press-ups, downward dogs and animal flow moves.

What I hope never to do again is... Go to the shops at 6am to make sure I get at least some fresh veg for the week.

What I would love to keep doing but probably shouldn't... Leave my pull-up rig up in the background of Zoom calls. The gym rings just prompt too many questions.

Harry de Quetteville  on the tech that connected usSo how many video conferencing apps do you have installed now, eh? Who imagined there could be so many, jostling for screen space and disk space, desperately claiming to be Numero Uno at keeping you face to face with your office/your chums/your children's virtual birthday party invitees...?Skype we knew. And FaceTime too. But then came Zoom. Don't forget Hangouts. Or Slack. Or Teams. Did you get round to GoToMeeting?Will Houseparty, that blazing star of lockdown's early days, downloaded 17 million times in March, continue to soar across the virtual firmament now that measures are easing? I'm not sure.But in general all those tools that allowed us effortlessly to toil and play remotely are staying, as the long-term impacts of the pandemic - smaller offices, genuine flexitime, distance learning and working - make themselves felt.The limiting factor will not be desire but internet speeds. How many happy hipsters relocating from Hackney to Hampshire will find that the new virtual tools of their trade require more than piddling rural bandwidth? As for that mobile signal...Social media, we know already, will go unreformed. How quickly the solidarity of those early days broke down into the usual political bickering and point-scoring.On Instagram, there were perhaps marginally fewer humblebrag pictures - "just relaxing in the amazing Highland landscape" - as urbanites hunkered down and realised that rubbing their lockdown escape in other people's faces was not the done thing, indeed was potentially illegal. "We're all in this together" is the very antithesis of the bitter spirit that fuels some social media envy-engines. But sadly, gentler ways have already faded online.For some, of course, virtual meetings have actually been an improvement. GPs have whizzed through the appointments. The bias towards remote consultations will stay - so much cheaper, more efficient, allowing more time for those that really need the in-person treatment.My parents-in-law rhapsodise about the app they use to play Bridge remotely, no driving to and fro, no tedious shuffling cards or tallying points. Plenty of chance to chat over an open phone line.The pandemic has even breached that previously impervious legislative barrier: the Highway Act 1835, in combination with the Road Traffic Act 1988, which made electric scooters illegal wherever you took them: road, cycle lane or pavement.This very week, a 12-month trial has begun, sanctioned by the Government, to see how electric scooters fit into the urban transport mix. Surely they are here to stay, especially as suspicion of enclosed and often crowded public transport endures.Indeed, tech generally has been the big winner this pandemic, as you will know if you follow the share prices of Silicon Valley's finest. Not only have the world's biggest companies stepped in to ensure personal connectivity, they have been swiftly ushered into state-like business - just look at the NHS partnering with big tech, or the deployment by nations of the Apple/Google tracing app.There is little that now seems beyond the reach of the biggest companies. So the most significant question post-lockdown will be this: will there be a backlash against their pervasiveness and power?During lockdown, if anything, latitude was granted. The UK Information Commissioner's Office announced that firms would have longer than usual to fix data breaches. Corona concerns saw Amazon's investment in Deliveroo approved by the Competition and Markets Authority, which also shied away from a full investigation of the online advertising industry so dominated by Facebook and Google.But now lockdown is easing, regulation may climb back up the political agenda. Too Big to Fail became a critical issue in the financial crisis. Too big to catch, to compete with, to scrutinise properly, to do without, may soon be the issue for big tech. If that is so, our corona love affair with technology may be heading for a big break-up.I'm persisting with...

Video conferencing. With my parents down the road, or tech wizards in the US, it's staying.

What I hope never to do again is... Home schooling. The tech made it possible. But there weren't enough hours in the day.

What I'd love to keep doing but probably shouldn't... Working from home. I love it. But I suspect I'll drift back to the office when it opens again.
