urn:contentItem:5W2X-XYN1-F021-63YT-00000-00'We lost control of our creations': the Silicon Valley heretic on a mission to make Big Tech repent2019-05-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:44:41ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1'We lost control of our creations': the Silicon Valley heretic on a mission to make Big Tech repentBy Laurence Dodds, US Technology Reporter

"Honestly, I feel like I had to go through depression to come to terms with what technology was doing," says Aza Raskin. He is sitting, wide-eyed, intense, in his office in a co-working space in downtown San Francisco.

"Unless you've felt it, unless you've cried over the fact that we really thought we were making the world a better place with the internet..." He pauses. "We 100 per cent believed that."

Humanity, he says, is living through "two super old stories. One: be careful what you wish for, because you'll get it... And two: creators losing control of their creations." 

He should know, because he is one of those Dr Frankensteins. As the son of Silicon Valley royalty (or at least nobility), he spent years merrily building technology that he believed was changing the world. It did, but not in the way that he hoped.

Now he is now at the heart of the backlash against Big Tech as one of the public faces of the Centre for Humane Technology, a non-profit group that he founded with former Google product manager Tristan Harris ( whom the Telegraph interviewed last year ) and "social impact" consultant Randy Fernando. Though the Centre was only founded last February, its influence is growing throughout the industry that it is trying to reform.

"There are two types of dystopias and we missed one of them," Mr Raskin tells the Telegraph. "There's the Orwell dystopia" - referencing George Orwell's 1984 - "and the Huxley dystopia" - a reference to Aldous Huxley's altogether stranger and more subtle 1932 novel Brave New World. 

"In the Orwell dystopia people don't read books because they're banned," he says. "In The Huxley dystopia people don't read books because they're distracted... In the Orwell dystopia, the things that we fear will get us. And in the Huxley dystopia things that we desire will get us."

'The end of human agency'

This cause has already notched up one victory, albeit a partial one. In 2013, Mr Harris spread around a presentation inside Google warning that its design practices were exploiting people's psychology to steal their time. He urged his colleagues instead to use their power over millions of Android phones and Chrome web browsers to "minimise distractions" and create "calmer states of mind".

Google made him a "design ethicist", but he did not feel he was making a difference, and by 2016 he had left Google to campaign full-time under the slogan of "time well spent". Two years later, Mark Zuckerberg had adopted the motto for himself, proclaiming it the new goal of Facebook's news feed algorithms, while Google and Apple   added new time management feature s features to their smartphones. It was hardly the revolution Mr Harris had hoped for, but it was a start.  

So now he and Mr Raskin are preaching a new gospel, which they call "human downgrading". The phrase is the fruit of a series of manic brainstorming sessions in San Francisco and at the Esalen Institute, a new age retreat on the California coastline. Unlike "time well spent", it is a dark and ominous vision. 

At a jazz hall in San Francisco last month, the pair gathered an audience of celebrities (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), activists (Wael Ghonim, a computer engineer who helped kickstart the Arab Spring in Egypt) and tech luminaries, from powerful industry figures (Rob Goldman, Facebook's vice president of advertising) to longtime critics (Justin Rosenstein, the disenchanted inventor of the like button). Then they issued a warning: tech giants are creating the cultural equivalent of climate change.

Addiction, distraction, disinformation, polarisation and radicalisation; all these "hurricanes", Mr Raskin and Mr Harris argue, have one common cause. They come from the fact that we now spend large portions of our lives inside artificial social systems, which are run by private companies for profit.

That would be fine  if their profits came from making us better human beings, but instead they are part of an "extractive attention economy", where money is made through the capture of time and attention. The phrase recalls the work of Shoshana Zuboff, a sociologist who argued in her book Surveillance Capitalism  that social networks are more like strip-miners than service providers, using data as "raw material" for their real products.

These factors together have created a "race to the bottom of the brainstem", in which increasingly "overwhelming" and sophisticated AI tools are devoted to exploiting what Mr Raskin calls the "soft underbelly of our animal minds". 

They even propose something more sinister: that these AIs have learned to make us more anxious and more confused, because these qualities make us better customers (or rather, more lucrative eyeballs). That, says Mr Harris, puts us at "a civilisational moment" - a crossroads where the wrong turn could mean "the end of human agency". 

From faith into despair

That was not what Mr Raskin imagined when he first started fooling around with computers as a child, growing up in a playfully unorthodox Jewish household with the father of the Apple Macintosh.

Aza Raskin was raised in Silicon Valley, for his dad. Jef Raskin, was a pioneer of computer interface design. Working at Apple, he led the Macintosh project in its early days and skirmished with Steve Jobs over whether the new machine should be capable of displaying bitmap images. Raskin senior was adamant it should; he wanted users to be able to compose music.

"I've always been a recreational weirdo," says Aza. He credits his dad with the teaching that interesting things are always "at the edges of fields", and with an urge to think deeply about what technology is really for. (Jef Raskin passed away in 2005.)

Aza followed in his father's footsteps. He co-founded Humanized, an interface design company, which was acquired by Mozilla, the makers of the Firefox browser, where he then worked for several years. He founded Songza, an early music streaming service that now powers Google Music's playlists.

He also co-founded Massive Health, which aimed to help users develop healthier habits through many of them same psychological tricks he now thinks are turning the world upside down.

"Always there was a vision to make the world a better place," he says. "The assumption [was that] if you want to change the world and make it better, the best way to do that is to make an app or a start-up."

Massive, for instance, used "streaks" - rewards for continuous app use, for which Snapchat has been roundly criticised - and "aspirational" social groups, like those which inspire such jealousy and longing on Instagram. He says the app drove an 11pc increase in users' exercise. Slowly, however, his doubts "snuck up behind" him like a shadow.

"The realisation started to hit that these techniques are very powerful," he says. "They're agnostic to what kind of goal they're pointed at... we're like, 'oh no. This could be used for all sorts of other things.'"

It was in 2017, running a new venture, a messaging company called Post Social, that he finally lost faith. Even though he was trying to fix some of the problems of social media, he found himself being sucked into the same metrics of success: how many users, how long they spend, how often they come back. "I was stuck running a company where I no longer believed in the mission," he says. "[It was] Kierkegaardian despair: your past has been robbed of its meaning." 

One element of his past that now looked very different was his invention of the infinite scroll. Older readers may remember a distant time when you actually had to click "next" when you got to the bottom of a web page. Mr Raskin, inspired by the smooth movements of Google Maps, fixed all that (though others have claimed credit too).

"Don't force the user to ask for more content," he wrote in a blog post on the Humanized website in 2006. "Just give it to them." He even gave talks at other companies evangelising the feature.

His wish was granted, and swiftly "weaponised" to keep us endlessly refreshing our apps like gamblers desperately tugging the lever of a slot machine. Today Mr Raskin calculates, conservatively, that the infinite scroll wastes an extra 200,000 human lifetimes every day. 

How Silicon Valley lost its way

The story that Mr Raskin tells is one of blind faith and idealism. "The open source movement, the fact that we were removing gatekeepers, letting people decentralise creativity and have voice where there wasn't voice - you remember! That was super exciting!" he says.

What changed was that tech companies' incentives began to drift away from this vision. The way he tells it, the techopalypse was a process of highly focused intelligences - human, artificial and corporate - spinning out of control as they attempted to maximise what they had been told to maximise.

Founders optimised their companies to make profit. Companies built AI systems that were optimised for keeping people's attention. Those AI systems then selected content that was optimised for shock and high emotion.

"It came down to a misunderstanding of the word 'want'," he says. "When you talk to [Mark] Zuckerberg and the other executives, they say 'look what do you want us to do'? Make people read the Wall Street Journal, the Times, the Telegraph?"

"They're like, 'no, these are people's revealed preferences, this is what they really want. But that's not what they really want. It's what people can't help but look at."

Just look, he says, at the crisis of self-esteem on social media. He and Mr Harris blame social networks for a huge rise in teenage depression, though debate is still ongoing ( a recent study of 12,000 British teenagers concluded that the effect is "tiny").

"If I want to keep you as a user coming back, its' a lot of work to grab your attention every time," Mr Raskin explains. "But if I could modify your identity so you do it for me, that's way more efficient. How would I do that?

"If I could undermine your self-esteem so that you need the validation, and you're addicted to the attention, that would be neat. How about if I showed you every day that people liked you better if only you looked a little different?"

No wonder, he says, that 55pc of American plastic surgeons say they have seen patients who say they want to look better in selfies. 

Or take YouTube's recommendation engine. What is the idea that you would expect a human to promote if they were trying to make people spend more time on YouTube? That users cannot trust the mainstream media, and that only YouTubers tell the real truth. Funnily enough, such videos are often exactly what YouTube recommends.

The implication is that AI, in its blind quest to maximise the numbers, has hit upon strategies which modify our own brains. Mr Raskin admits this isn't a claim he can easily prove, but he finds the proliferation of conspiracy theories and fake exposés suggestive. It's not wildly implausible, because AI regularly discovers patterns that are invisible to humans: one system, called Deep Patient, can sometimes predict schizophrenia, but nobody knows how  it does so.

But doesn't this story give Silicon Valley too much credit? Not all of its leaders were innocent child geniuses who had no idea what the were creating. Sean Parker, an early Facebook executive, tells it differently, saying that he, Mark Zuckerberg and friends knew exactly what they were doing - "and did it anyway".

"I completely agree!" says Mr Raskin. "There is so much culpability, do not get me wrong." But the tech industry contains all sorts, he argues, and what really matters are the incentives they work under.

"Even if you had a different Facebook and a different YouTube, they'd still be focused on the same kinds of forces," he says. Just as the human cultures that were willing to see animals as resources outcompeted those which refused to farm or slaughter, the companies that "learn to treat human beings as resources to exploit" will outcompete those that take a higher road.

What can be done?

How, then, can all of this actually be stopped? Mr Harris's speech at the jazz club was mocked by some viewers for being vague on this point. He asked the audience to meditate and be aware of their breathing, and mentioned that CHT would soon launch a podcast. Bookmarks were given out calling on software designers to be "sophisticated about human nature". He mentioned roles for designers, journalists, politicians and voters, but gave little detail.

"In the end the only things that will make a substantive difference to the way these companies operate are damage to the bottom line (via bad PR or losing customers) or law and regulation," tweeted Tom Coates, a veteran tech blogger and friend of Mr Raskin.

"If you don't engage with those questions, if you argue for a better world but don't get involved in the gritty fights... then I thank you for your lovely dream, but that's all it is."

And ethical AI that is supportive to people will only be paid for if it makes more money than unethical AI, and even then we won't necessarily get rid of it because there'll always be a niche of money somewhere for a bottom feeder to exploit.- Tom Coates (@tomcoates) https://twitter.com/tomcoates/status/1120852413429080065?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwApril 24, 2019

Speaking to the Telegraph, though Mr Raskin is more specific. He welcomes US regulators' expected $3-5bn (£2.3-3.8bn) fine against Facebook for the Cambridge Analytica scandal, but says it is treating the symptom, not the cause. Instead, systemic problems require a systemic approach, making the practices that cause social harm too expensive to be worthwhile.

One way would be to modify safe harbour rules, which protect social networks for liability for the content their users post. Instead of making them fully liable like a newspaper is, Mr Raskin suggests they should be liable for any content that they algorithmically "promote". "That really starts to change the incentive landscape," he says.

Another proposal is to give tech firms a fiduciary duty towards their users, even stricter than the duty of care for which the Telegraph has been campaigning. Just as doctors and stockbrokers are bound to act in their clients' best interests, on pain of being sued, so tech firms should be held to a higher standard of good faith.

The power of their AI systems, Mr Raskin says, has become so great that there is an inescapable asymmetry between them and their users. Since that AI is powered by our data - the digital equivalent of our "toenail clippings and hair" - its makers should be punished for betraying our trust.

Such top-down solutions, he freely admits, are a necessary part of the puzzle, but the will require public pressure. "That only happens when enough people care about it and can articulate what they care about and can ask for it from the government," he says. That is one reason why he and Mr Harris spent so much time coming up with the phrase "human downgrading". They consider it a banner people can rally around.

Converting tech workers, one soul at a time

Most of all, though, Mr Raskin believes there must be cultural, even spiritual change in Silicon Valley.

He has mixed feelings about the success of "time well spent": on the one hand, it was the first time companies really accepted responsibility, "and that's positive and great"; on the other hand, he is not impressed by the smartphone makers' new time-management features.

"For them it was a PR problem, and they gave a PR solution," he says. "It almost feels like they're gaslighting us: we've made this thing that's hyper-addictive, and it's your fault if you use it. It's like, 'we're going to put a calendar inside of every cigarette box where you can check off how many days you didn't smoke." 

Nevertheless, it showed that tech firms can be pressured into changing their behaviour from the inside as well as the outside. "Pressure isn't a physical object, right?" he says. "It means you're Zuckerberg and you're walking down the hall and three people mention something to you, 'time well spent'. Somebody on the board mentioning it to you, seeing a news article mentioning it to you, and all of a sudden you're like 'oh, I'm sort of surrounded. This is a thing people care about.'"

He quotes Margaret Read's aphorism: "Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has." In his view, tech workers are that small group, and by changing their minds he can "ship a product to a billion phones without writing a single line of code".

That means more tech workers will have to go through the moral crisis that he did. "Every mourns in a different way," he says. "But... some process like that, people need to go through." He sees encouraging signs of this, citing "whistleblowers" such as Guillaume Chaslot, who helped build YouTube's recommendation engine and is now at war with it.

A change in culture would mean a change in design practices. For example, companies could deliberately slow down web pages and buttons at certain points in order to "give our brains a chance to catch up". Mr Raskin cites an experiment performed by Amazon, which found that for every 100 milliseconds slower its web page loaded, it lost 1pc of its sales.

A design guide put out by the Centre for Humane Technology urges designers to be far more cautious of a range of specific features, such as "artificial scarcity", "urgency signalling", "over-personalised filters" and "quantified social status". It suggests that they avoid "implied obligation", limit viral sharing and insert "cues" into their systems which give their users regular opportunities to stop their browsing.

Not everyone is convinced

While many tech workers have warmed to Mr Raskin's mission, others remain sceptical. He and Mr Harris have been criticised not only by Valley insiders but by people who should in theory be his natural allies.

One criticism is that the pair seem ignorant of earlier attempts to rein in Big Tech. Activists and scholars have been warning for years that Facebook had grown too large, that Google had grown too powerful, that algorithms were a ticking time bomb of disinformation and corruption of public debate.

Evgeny Morozov, a reliably grumpy scholar of the internet originally born in censorship-ridden Belarus, wrote The Net Delusion, his landmark critique of "cyber-utopianism", in 2011. Neil Postman (who, to be fair, Mr Raskin cites approvingly) warned that "every technology has a philosophy" in 1998. Michael Goldhaber coined the term "attention economy" in 1997.

Maybe if tech workers had been paying attention in 2005 or even in 2010, the critics say, none of this would have happened.

A bigger objection is that Mr Raskin's mission represents an attempt to dismantle Big Tech using the tools of Big Tech. Both he and Mr Harris are technologists through and through; they speak that language and share that worldview. Mr Harris even called for a "full-stack understanding" of human nature - a piece of engineering jargon usually applied to the suite of tools used to build a given product.

So isn't this just another example of tech-savvy, affluent white men believing they can change the world with systems thinking? Mark Hurst, a product consultant, put it this way: "The scandalous truth is that we need to use tech less, put our faith in tech less, and ultimately assign less power to Silicon Valley. Tech is not going to solve this mess."

Tech insiders diagnosing how tech is designed wrong: helpful! We need that insider view, thanks!Tech insiders selling us more tech as the solution: not so helpful! (Perhaps we could hear about solutions from people who didn't create the problem in the first place! Thanks!!)- Mark Hurst (@markhurst) https://twitter.com/markhurst/status/1120772339518586882?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwApril 23, 2019

In a statement, a spokeswoman for the Centre for Humane Technology said its founders' experience in the tech industry was "an advantage", not a handicap.

"Our world-class team of deeply concerned former tech insiders intimately understands the culture, incentives, design techniques, and organisational structures driving human downgrading," she said.

And Mr Raskin is adamant that the tools his generation built cannot simply be banished. "It's not that we want to use [them] for good," he insists. "It's that we've already built these levers of power. They already exist. And now the question is do we want to put our hands on the steering wheel intentionally, or turn our backs and let the extractive attention economy drive it? We're seeing what that does."

In the long run, he argues nations that let their people be divided and exploited will lose ground against nations such as China, which is building a massive system of digital behavioural modification based on very different values. 

For now, he is committed to converting his former peers in the tech industry, believing they can truly drive change. "The last woman who came up to me was from YouTube, and she was like 'I don't know if I can work where I'm working anymore'," he says. "People are just thankful that somebody is able to articulate what they've been feeling."

Addiction, distraction, disinformation, polarisation and radicalisation; all these "hurricanes", Mr Raskin and Mr Harris argue, have one common cause. They come from the fact that we now spend large portions of our lives inside artificial social systems, which are run by private companies for profit.

That would be fine  if their profits came from making us better human beings, but instead they are part of an "extractive attention economy", where money is made through the capture of time and attention. The phrase recalls the work of Shoshana Zuboff, a sociologist who argued in her book Surveillance Capitalism  that social networks are more like strip-miners than service providers, using data as "raw material" for their real products.

These factors together have created a "race to the bottom of the brainstem", in which increasingly "overwhelming" and sophisticated AI tools are devoted to exploiting what Mr Raskin calls the "soft underbelly of our animal minds". 

They even propose something more sinister: that these AIs have learned to make us more anxious and more confused, because these qualities make us better customers (or rather, more lucrative eyeballs). That, says Mr Harris, puts us at "a civilisational moment" - a crossroads where the wrong turn could mean "the end of human agency". 

From faith into despair

That was not what Mr Raskin imagined when he first started fooling around with computers as a child, growing up in a playfully unorthodox Jewish household with the father of the Apple Macintosh.

Aza Raskin was raised in Silicon Valley, for his dad. Jef Raskin, was a pioneer of computer interface design. Working at Apple, he led the Macintosh project in its early days and skirmished with Steve Jobs over whether the new machine should be capable of displaying bitmap images. Raskin senior was adamant it should; he wanted users to be able to compose music.

"I've always been a recreational weirdo," says Aza. He credits his dad with the teaching that interesting things are always "at the edges of fields", and with an urge to think deeply about what technology is really for. (Jef Raskin passed away in 2005.)

Aza followed in his father's footsteps. He co-founded Humanized, an interface design company, which was acquired by Mozilla, the makers of the Firefox browser, where he then worked for several years. He founded Songza, an early music streaming service that now powers Google Music's playlists.

He also co-founded Massive Health, which aimed to help users develop healthier habits through many of them same psychological tricks he now thinks are turning the world upside down.

"Always there was a vision to make the world a better place," he says. "The assumption [was that] if you want to change the world and make it better, the best way to do that is to make an app or a start-up."

Massive, for instance, used "streaks" - rewards for continuous app use, for which Snapchat has been roundly criticised - and "aspirational" social groups, like those which inspire such jealousy and longing on Instagram. He says the app drove an 11pc increase in users' exercise. Slowly, however, his doubts "snuck up behind" him like a shadow.

"The realisation started to hit that these techniques are very powerful," he says. "They're agnostic to what kind of goal they're pointed at... we're like, 'oh no. This could be used for all sorts of other things.'"

It was in 2017, running a new venture, a messaging company called Post Social, that he finally lost faith. Even though he was trying to fix some of the problems of social media, he found himself being sucked into the same metrics of success: how many users, how long they spend, how often they come back. "I was stuck running a company where I no longer believed in the mission," he says. "[It was] Kierkegaardian despair: your past has been robbed of its meaning." 

One element of his past that now looked very different was his invention of the infinite scroll. Older readers may remember a distant time when you actually had to click "next" when you got to the bottom of a web page. Mr Raskin, inspired by the smooth movements of Google Maps, fixed all that (though others have claimed credit too).

"Don't force the user to ask for more content," he wrote in a blog post on the Humanized website in 2006. "Just give it to them." He even gave talks at other companies evangelising the feature.

His wish was granted, and swiftly "weaponised" to keep us endlessly refreshing our apps like gamblers desperately tugging the lever of a slot machine. Today Mr Raskin calculates, conservatively, that the infinite scroll wastes an extra 200,000 human lifetimes every day. 

How Silicon Valley lost its way

The story that Mr Raskin tells is one of blind faith and idealism. "The open source movement, the fact that we were removing gatekeepers, letting people decentralise creativity and have voice where there wasn't voice - you remember! That was super exciting!" he says.

What changed was that tech companies' incentives began to drift away from this vision. The way he tells it, the techopalypse was a process of highly focused intelligences - human, artificial and corporate - spinning out of control as they attempted to maximise what they had been told to maximise.

Founders optimised their companies to make profit. Companies built AI systems that were optimised for keeping people's attention. Those AI systems then selected content that was optimised for shock and high emotion.

"It came down to a misunderstanding of the word 'want'," he says. "When you talk to [Mark] Zuckerberg and the other executives, they say 'look what do you want us to do'? Make people read the Wall Street Journal, the Times, the Telegraph?"

"They're like, 'no, these are people's revealed preferences, this is what they really want. But that's not what they really want. It's what people can't help but look at."

Just look, he says, at the crisis of self-esteem on social media. He and Mr Harris blame social networks for a huge rise in teenage depression, though debate is still ongoing ( a recent study of 12,000 British teenagers concluded that the effect is "tiny").

"If I want to keep you as a user coming back, its' a lot of work to grab your attention every time," Mr Raskin explains. "But if I could modify your identity so you do it for me, that's way more efficient. How would I do that?

"If I could undermine your self-esteem so that you need the validation, and you're addicted to the attention, that would be neat. How about if I showed you every day that people liked you better if only you looked a little different?"

No wonder, he says, that 55pc of American plastic surgeons say they have seen patients who say they want to look better in selfies. 

Or take YouTube's recommendation engine. What is the idea that you would expect a human to promote if they were trying to make people spend more time on YouTube? That users cannot trust the mainstream media, and that only YouTubers tell the real truth. Funnily enough, such videos are often exactly what YouTube recommends.

The implication is that AI, in its blind quest to maximise the numbers, has hit upon strategies which modify our own brains. Mr Raskin admits this isn't a claim he can easily prove, but he finds the proliferation of conspiracy theories and fake exposés suggestive. It's not wildly implausible, because AI regularly discovers patterns that are invisible to humans: one system, called Deep Patient, can sometimes predict schizophrenia, but nobody knows how  it does so.

But doesn't this story give Silicon Valley too much credit? Not all of its leaders were innocent child geniuses who had no idea what the were creating. Sean Parker, an early Facebook executive, tells it differently, saying that he, Mark Zuckerberg and friends knew exactly what they were doing - "and did it anyway".

"I completely agree!" says Mr Raskin. "There is so much culpability, do not get me wrong." But the tech industry contains all sorts, he argues, and what really matters are the incentives they work under.

"Even if you had a different Facebook and a different YouTube, they'd still be focused on the same kinds of forces," he says. Just as the human cultures that were willing to see animals as resources outcompeted those which refused to farm or slaughter, the companies that "learn to treat human beings as resources to exploit" will outcompete those that take a higher road.

What can be done?

How, then, can all of this actually be stopped? Mr Harris's speech at the jazz club was mocked by some viewers for being vague on this point. He asked the audience to meditate and be aware of their breathing, and mentioned that CHT would soon launch a podcast. Bookmarks were given out calling on software designers to be "sophisticated about human nature". He mentioned roles for designers, journalists, politicians and voters, but gave little detail.

"In the end the only things that will make a substantive difference to the way these companies operate are damage to the bottom line (via bad PR or losing customers) or law and regulation," tweeted Tom Coates, a veteran tech blogger and friend of Mr Raskin.

"If you don't engage with those questions, if you argue for a better world but don't get involved in the gritty fights... then I thank you for your lovely dream, but that's all it is."

And ethical AI that is supportive to people will only be paid for if it makes more money than unethical AI, and even then we won't necessarily get rid of it because there'll always be a niche of money somewhere for a bottom feeder to exploit.- Tom Coates (@tomcoates) https://twitter.com/tomcoates/status/1120852413429080065?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwApril 24, 2019

Speaking to the Telegraph, though Mr Raskin is more specific. He welcomes US regulators' expected $3-5bn (£2.3-3.8bn) fine against Facebook for the Cambridge Analytica scandal, but says it is treating the symptom, not the cause. Instead, systemic problems require a systemic approach, making the practices that cause social harm too expensive to be worthwhile.

One way would be to modify safe harbour rules, which protect social networks for liability for the content their users post. Instead of making them fully liable like a newspaper is, Mr Raskin suggests they should be liable for any content that they algorithmically "promote". "That really starts to change the incentive landscape," he says.

Another proposal is to give tech firms a fiduciary duty towards their users, even stricter than the duty of care for which the Telegraph has been campaigning. Just as doctors and stockbrokers are bound to act in their clients' best interests, on pain of being sued, so tech firms should be held to a higher standard of good faith.

The power of their AI systems, Mr Raskin says, has become so great that there is an inescapable asymmetry between them and their users. Since that AI is powered by our data - the digital equivalent of our "toenail clippings and hair" - its makers should be punished for betraying our trust.

Such top-down solutions, he freely admits, are a necessary part of the puzzle, but the will require public pressure. "That only happens when enough people care about it and can articulate what they care about and can ask for it from the government," he says. That is one reason why he and Mr Harris spent so much time coming up with the phrase "human downgrading". They consider it a banner people can rally around.

Converting tech workers, one soul at a time

Most of all, though, Mr Raskin believes there must be cultural, even spiritual change in Silicon Valley.

He has mixed feelings about the success of "time well spent": on the one hand, it was the first time companies really accepted responsibility, "and that's positive and great"; on the other hand, he is not impressed by the smartphone makers' new time-management features.

"For them it was a PR problem, and they gave a PR solution," he says. "It almost feels like they're gaslighting us: we've made this thing that's hyper-addictive, and it's your fault if you use it. It's like, 'we're going to put a calendar inside of every cigarette box where you can check off how many days you didn't smoke." 

Nevertheless, it showed that tech firms can be pressured into changing their behaviour from the inside as well as the outside. "Pressure isn't a physical object, right?" he says. "It means you're Zuckerberg and you're walking down the hall and three people mention something to you, 'time well spent'. Somebody on the board mentioning it to you, seeing a news article mentioning it to you, and all of a sudden you're like 'oh, I'm sort of surrounded. This is a thing people care about.'"

He quotes Margaret Read's aphorism: "Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has." In his view, tech workers are that small group, and by changing their minds he can "ship a product to a billion phones without writing a single line of code".

That means more tech workers will have to go through the moral crisis that he did. "Every mourns in a different way," he says. "But... some process like that, people need to go through." He sees encouraging signs of this, citing "whistleblowers" such as Guillaume Chaslot, who helped build YouTube's recommendation engine and is now at war with it.

A change in culture would mean a change in design practices. For example, companies could deliberately slow down web pages and buttons at certain points in order to "give our brains a chance to catch up". Mr Raskin cites an experiment performed by Amazon, which found that for every 100 milliseconds slower its web page loaded, it lost 1pc of its sales.

A design guide put out by the Centre for Humane Technology urges designers to be far more cautious of a range of specific features, such as "artificial scarcity", "urgency signalling", "over-personalised filters" and "quantified social status". It suggests that they avoid "implied obligation", limit viral sharing and insert "cues" into their systems which give their users regular opportunities to stop their browsing.

Not everyone is convinced

While many tech workers have warmed to Mr Raskin's mission, others remain sceptical. He and Mr Harris have been criticised not only by Valley insiders but by people who should in theory be his natural allies.

One criticism is that the pair seem ignorant of earlier attempts to rein in Big Tech. Activists and scholars have been warning for years that Facebook had grown too large, that Google had grown too powerful, that algorithms were a ticking time bomb of disinformation and corruption of public debate.

Evgeny Morozov, a reliably grumpy scholar of the internet originally born in censorship-ridden Belarus, wrote The Net Delusion, his landmark critique of "cyber-utopianism", in 2011. Neil Postman (who, to be fair, Mr Raskin cites approvingly) warned that "every technology has a philosophy" in 1998. Michael Goldhaber coined the term "attention economy" in 1997.

Maybe if tech workers had been paying attention in 2005 or even in 2010, the critics say, none of this would have happened.

A bigger objection is that Mr Raskin's mission represents an attempt to dismantle Big Tech using the tools of Big Tech. Both he and Mr Harris are technologists through and through; they speak that language and share that worldview. Mr Harris even called for a "full-stack understanding" of human nature - a piece of engineering jargon usually applied to the suite of tools used to build a given product.

So isn't this just another example of tech-savvy, affluent white men believing they can change the world with systems thinking? Mark Hurst, a product consultant, put it this way: "The scandalous truth is that we need to use tech less, put our faith in tech less, and ultimately assign less power to Silicon Valley. Tech is not going to solve this mess."

Tech insiders diagnosing how tech is designed wrong: helpful! We need that insider view, thanks!Tech insiders selling us more tech as the solution: not so helpful! (Perhaps we could hear about solutions from people who didn't create the problem in the first place! Thanks!!)- Mark Hurst (@markhurst) https://twitter.com/markhurst/status/1120772339518586882?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwApril 23, 2019

In a statement, a spokeswoman for the Centre for Humane Technology said its founders' experience in the tech industry was "an advantage", not a handicap.

"Our world-class team of deeply concerned former tech insiders intimately understands the culture, incentives, design techniques, and organisational structures driving human downgrading," she said.

And Mr Raskin is adamant that the tools his generation built cannot simply be banished. "It's not that we want to use [them] for good," he insists. "It's that we've already built these levers of power. They already exist. And now the question is do we want to put our hands on the steering wheel intentionally, or turn our backs and let the extractive attention economy drive it? We're seeing what that does."

In the long run, he argues nations that let their people be divided and exploited will lose ground against nations such as China, which is building a massive system of digital behavioural modification based on very different values. 

For now, he is committed to converting his former peers in the tech industry, believing they can truly drive change. "The last woman who came up to me was from YouTube, and she was like 'I don't know if I can work where I'm working anymore'," he says. "People are just thankful that somebody is able to articulate what they've been feeling."
